Does Graph Prompt Work? A Data Operation Perspective with Theoretical Analysis

Qunzhong Wang, Xiangguo Sunâˆ—, Hong Cheng.
Department of Systems Engineering and Engineering Management,
and Shun Hing Institute of Advanced Engineering
The Chinese University of Hong Kong
1155210998@link.cuhk.edu.hk, xiangguosun@cuhk.edu.hk
hcheng@se.cuhk.edu.hk Co-first AuthorsCorrespondence to: Xiangguo Sun (xiangguosun@cuhk.edu.hk)
Abstract

In recent years, graph prompting has emerged as a promising research direction, enabling the learning of additional tokens or subgraphs appended to the original graphs without requiring retraining of pre-trained graph models across various applications. This novel paradigm, shifting from the traditional â€œpre-training and fine-tuningâ€ to â€œpre-training and promptingâ€ has shown significant empirical success in simulating graph data operations, with applications ranging from recommendation systems to biological networks and graph transferring. However, despite its potential, the theoretical underpinnings of graph prompting remain underexplored, raising critical questions about its fundamental effectiveness. The lack of rigorous theoretical proof of why and how much it works is more like a â€œdark cloudâ€ over the graph prompt area to go further. To fill this gap, this paper introduces a theoretical framework that rigorously analyzes graph prompting from a data operation perspective. Our contributions are threefold: First, we provide a formal guarantee theorem, demonstrating graph promptsâ€™ capacity to approximate graph transformation operators, effectively linking upstream and downstream tasks. Second, we derive upper bounds on the error of these data operations by graph prompts for a single graph and extend this discussion to batches of graphs, which are common in graph model training. Third, we analyze the distribution of data operation errors, extending our theoretical findings from linear graph models (e.g., GCN) to non-linear graph models (e.g., GAT). Extensive experiments support our theoretical results and confirm the practical implications of these guarantees.

1 Introduction

Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have been widely used in analyzing various graph-structured data. A standard workflow using GNNs is the â€œpre-training and fine-tuningâ€ paradigm, where a model is first trained on a large-scale, general-purpose dataset and then fine-tuned on a specific downstream task. While this method has been effective in transferring learned representations, it often needs many advanced tricks to retrain the model parameters for each new task, which can be computationally intensive and may not fully capture the unique characteristics of the downstream tasks, potentially limiting the modelâ€™s generalization.

Inspired by the success of prompting techniques in natural language processing (NLP), there has been a growing interest in adapting similar ideas to graph data through â€œpre-training and promptingâ€. Graph prompts (Sun etÂ al., 2023b) modify the input graphs by adding learnable tokens or subgraphs, enabling the pre-trained GNN to better align with the requirements of downstream tasks without tuning the model parameters. Many empirical works (Sun etÂ al., 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2023; Tan etÂ al., 2023; Huang etÂ al., 2023; Ma etÂ al., 2023; Chen etÂ al., 2024) have found that graph prompting can reduce computational overhead, preserve the generality of the pre-trained model, and allow for seamless application across multiple tasks to achieve better expressive capability than the traditional paradigm.

Recently, some studies (Fang etÂ al., 2024; Sun etÂ al., 2023a) have realized that the reason why graph prompts work may relate to their capability in simulating various data operations like deleting/adding nodes/edges, changing node features, and even removing subgraphs. This makes graph prompts stand out from their counterpart in the NLP area and inspires many empirical applications like recommendation systems (Yang etÂ al., 2023; 2024; Wang etÂ al., 2024), biological networks (Diao etÂ al., 2022; Gao etÂ al., 2024), transferring knowledge across different graph domains (Guo etÂ al., 2023; Zhu etÂ al., 2024b; Zhao etÂ al., 2024), and more (Jin etÂ al., 2024). Unfortunately, despite these promising results, the theoretical basis of graph prompting remains underexplored. Existing works primarily rely on empirical validation and lack rigorous theoretical analysis to explain why graph prompts are effective and how they can be systematically designed. This gap is just like a â€œdark couldâ€ over the graph prompt area, raising critical questions about their broader applications and the development of more advanced methods that could leverage their full potential.

In light of these limitations, this paper provides a comprehensive theoretical framework for graph prompting from a data operation perspective. First, we establish rigorous guarantee theorems that demonstrate the underlying reason why graph prompts work is their capacity to simulate various graph data operations, and our theorems further answer why such capacity can make the pre-trained model meet new task requirements without retraining. Second, we derive upper bounds on the error introduced by graph prompts when simulating these data operations. We analyze this error for individual graphs and extend our discussion to batches of graphs, which is crucial for understanding the scalability and generalization of graph prompts in practical scenarios where models are usually trained on multiple graphs. Third, we explore the distribution of the data operation error and extend our theoretical findings from linear graph models, such as Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs), to non-linear models like Graph Attention Networks (GATs). This extension demonstrates the robustness of our theoretical framework across different GNN architectures and provides insights into how non-linearity affects the effectiveness of graph prompts. We conduct extensive experiments to confirm our theoretical findings. By offering such a solid theoretical foundation for graph prompting, our work advances the understanding of how and why graph prompts work, guides for designing more effective prompting techniques, and empowers researchers and practitioners to leverage them with greater confidence in various applications.

2 Background

Graph Prompt. Compared with â€œpre-training and fine-tuningâ€, which first trains a graph model via some easily accessible task on the graph dataset and then tries to adapt the model to a new task (or even a new graph dataset), â€œpre-training and promptingâ€ aims to keep the pre-trained model unchanged but adjust the input data to make the downstream task compatible with the pre-training task. Mathematically, let FÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒF_{\theta^{*}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a graph model where its parameters (Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) have been pre-trained and frozen; Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤T_{dow}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the downstream task, in which the task objective is measured by a loss function â„’Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptâ„’subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤\mathcal{L}_{T_{dow}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G be a graph dataset and each graph instance Gâˆˆğ’¢ğºğ’¢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G âˆˆ caligraphic_G can be denoted as G=(ğ’±,â„°,ğ—,ğ€)ğºğ’±â„°ğ—ğ€G=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E},\mathbf{X},\mathbf{A})italic_G = ( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E , bold_X , bold_A ) where ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V denotes the node set with a node feature matrix ğ—âˆˆâ„|ğ’±|Ã—Fğ—superscriptâ„ğ’±ğ¹\mathbf{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{V}|\times F}bold_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_V | Ã— italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; â„°â„°\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E denotes the edge set and the connection of nodes can be further indicated by the adjacent matrix ğ€âˆˆ{0,1}|ğ’±|Ã—|ğ’±|ğ€superscript01ğ’±ğ’±\mathbf{A}\in\{0,1\}^{|\mathcal{V}|\times|\mathcal{V}|}bold_A âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_V | Ã— | caligraphic_V | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote a parameterized graph prompt function with learnable Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰. In most cases, graph prompts consist of some token vectors or subgraphs which will be integrated into the original graph GğºGitalic_G. PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates how to define such graph prompts and how to combine them with the original graph to generate a new graph: GÏ‰=PÏ‰â¢(G)subscriptğºğœ”subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºG_{\omega}=P_{\omega}(G)italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ). Graph prompt learning aims to optimize the following target:

Ï‰âˆ—=argminÏ‰âˆ‘Gâˆˆğ’¢â„’Tdâ¢oâ¢w(FÎ¸âˆ—(PÏ‰(G))\omega^{*}=\arg\min_{\omega}\sum_{G\in\mathcal{G}}\mathcal{L}_{T_{dow}}(F_{% \theta^{*}}(P_{\omega}(G))italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G âˆˆ caligraphic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) ) (1)

Without loss of generality, we assume all these tasks are graph level (e.g., graph classification). That means FÎ¸â¢(G)subscriptğ¹ğœƒğºF_{\theta}(G)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) will output a graph-level embedding for the downstream task. For node-level and edge-level tasks, many studies (Sun etÂ al., 2023a; Liu etÂ al., 2023) have proved that we can always find solutions to translate these tasks to the graph-level task.

GPF and All-in-One. Current graph prompt designs, as described in the review by Sun etÂ al. (2023b), can be primarily categorized into two types: prompt as token vectors added to node features, and prompt as additional graph inserted to the original graph. In the rest of this paper, we focus on two representative frameworks: GPF (Fang etÂ al., 2022) as an example of adding extra prompt vectors, and All-in-One (Sun etÂ al., 2023a) as an example of adding prompt subgraphs. Our choice is motivated by our interest in simulating graph operations at a theoretical level. The GPF and All-in-One frameworks provide the most fundamental approaches among these methods. The rest graph prompt designs can usually be treated as their special cases or natural extensions.

Specifically, GPF aims to learn a token vector Ï‰âˆˆâ„1Ã—Fğœ”superscriptâ„1ğ¹\omega\in\mathbb{R}^{1\times F}italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 Ã— italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where Fğ¹Fitalic_F is the same dimension of the node features in the original graph, then the prompt token is directly added to each nodeâ€™s feature vector, making the original feature matrix ğ—={x1,â‹¯,xN}ğ—subscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘\mathbf{X}=\{x_{1},\cdots,x_{N}\}bold_X = { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } changed to ğ—Ï‰={x1+Ï‰,â‹¯,xN+Ï‰}subscriptğ—ğœ”subscriptğ‘¥1ğœ”â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğœ”\mathbf{X}_{\omega}=\{x_{1}+\omega,\cdots,x_{N}+\omega\}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ï‰ , â‹¯ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ï‰ }. In this way, the original graph G=(ğ’±,â„°,ğ—,ğ€)ğºğ’±â„°ğ—ğ€G=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E},\mathbf{X},\mathbf{A})italic_G = ( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E , bold_X , bold_A ) is changed to PÏ‰â¢(G)=GÏ‰=(ğ’±,â„°,ğ—Ï‰,ğ€)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºsubscriptğºğœ”ğ’±â„°subscriptğ—ğœ”ğ€P_{\omega}(G)=G_{\omega}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E},\mathbf{X}_{\omega},\mathbf{% A})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E , bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_A ).

All-in-One offers the prompt as a graph format by defining prompt tokens, token structures and inserting patterns. Let Î©âˆˆâ„kÃ—FÎ©superscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ¹\Omega\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times F}roman_Î© âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k Ã— italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the learnable matrix corresponding to Kğ¾Kitalic_K prompt tokens. Let ğ€iâ¢nâˆˆ{0,1}kÃ—ksubscriptğ€ğ‘–ğ‘›superscript01ğ‘˜ğ‘˜\mathbf{A}_{in}\in\{0,1\}^{k\times k}bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k Ã— italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT indicate token structures where Aiâ¢j=1subscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—1A_{ij}=1italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 means there is an inner link connecting the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th and the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th tokens and vice versa. Aiâ¢nsubscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘›A_{in}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be calculated by the inner product of these tokens. Similarly, the inserting pattern tells us how to connect each token to the original graph nodes, which is denoted by a cross matrix ğ€câ¢râ¢oâˆˆ{0,1}kÃ—Nsubscriptğ€ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œsuperscript01ğ‘˜ğ‘\mathbf{A}_{cro}\in\{0,1\}^{k\times N}bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_r italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k Ã— italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then the graph prompt changes the original graph GğºGitalic_G to GÏ‰=(ğ’±Ï‰,â„°Ï‰,ğ—,ğ›€,ğ€Ï‰)subscriptğºğœ”subscriptğ’±ğœ”subscriptâ„°ğœ”ğ—ğ›€subscriptğ€ğœ”G_{\omega}=(\mathcal{V}_{\omega},\mathcal{E}_{\omega},\mathbf{X},\mathbf{% \Omega},\mathbf{A}_{\omega})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_X , bold_Î© , bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where ğ’±Ï‰subscriptğ’±ğœ”\mathcal{V}_{\omega}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the collection of the original nodes and the token nodes; â„°Ï‰subscriptâ„°ğœ”\mathcal{E}_{\omega}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT includes the original edges, inner links among tokens and the cross links between tokens and the original nodes; ğ€Ï‰subscriptğ€ğœ”\mathbf{A}_{\omega}bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the collection of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A}bold_A,ğ€iâ¢nsubscriptğ€ğ‘–ğ‘›\mathbf{A}_{in}bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and ğ€câ¢râ¢osubscriptğ€ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œ\mathbf{A}_{cro}bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_r italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Motivations. Initially, Fang etÂ al. (2022) have proved that graph prompt can simulate any graph data operation (e.g., deleting/adding nodes/edges, changing node features, or removing subgraphs, etc). That means for any graph data operation tâ¢(â‹…)ğ‘¡â‹…t(\cdot)italic_t ( â‹… ), we can always learn a graph prompt reaching FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(GÏ‰)=FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(tâ¢(G))subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğœ”subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğºF_{\theta^{*}}(G_{\omega})=F_{\theta^{*}}(t(G))italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ( italic_G ) ). However, this equivalence needs a very strong precondition: the graph model Fğ¹Fitalic_F should not contain any non-linear layer, which is apparently very hard to meet in the practical solutions. Later, Sun etÂ al. (2023a) extended this finding with more advanced prompts and empirically observed that the error to such approximation FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(GÏ‰)â†’FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(tâ¢(G))â†’subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğœ”subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğºF_{\theta^{*}}(G_{\omega})\rightarrow F_{\theta^{*}}(t(G))italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â†’ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ( italic_G ) ) may relate to the non-linear layers of the graph model and the prompt design. However, these observations are not followed by a critical theory proof. Recently, there has been an increasing number of empirical works on graph prompts achieving success in various applications. Unfortunately, the theoretical basis of graph prompt is still very tumbledown and we still have not figured out why graph prompts work in theory, especially for questions like how powerful the graph prompt is in manipulating graph data? and why such capability works for downstream tasks?

In this paper, we go deeper in theory for the graph prompt capability of manipulating data. We conduct a comprehensive effectiveness analysis of general graph prompt learning through the concepts of â€œbridge setsâ€ and â€œÏµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended bridge setsâ€ (see in section 3.3). Based on extensive theoretical derivations and substantial experimental evidence, we establish theorems related to the error bound of graph prompts in simulating graph data operations. Our goal is to figure out in theory how this error changes from a single graph to a batch of graphs, from a linear model to a non-linear model, and which factors relate to this error. Through this work, we wish to push forward the graph prompt area with a more solid theory basis, help researchers to design more scientific graph prompt techniques, and offer them theory confidence for their further usage.

3 Why Graph Prompt Works? A Data Operation Perspective

Let FÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒF_{\theta^{*}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be any given GNN model that has been pre-trained on a given task Tpâ¢râ¢esubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’T_{pre}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_r italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT means the parameters have been determined and frozen. For a given graph instance Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{ori}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can expect the model to output appropriate graph-level embedding on Tpâ¢râ¢esubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’T_{pre}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_r italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because this model has already been trained on this task. However, when we try to use this model on a new task Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤T_{dow}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the output embedding, FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{ori})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), can not guarantee acceptable performance because the pre-training task Tpâ¢râ¢esubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’T_{pre}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_r italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may be incompatible with downstream tasks Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤T_{dow}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3.1 Perspective from Model Tuning

To fill this gap, â€œpre-training and fine-tuningâ€ aims to adapt the pre-trained model to a new version and wish it could perform better. Assume there exists an optimal function, say Cğ¶Citalic_C, which can map Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{ori}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the embedding Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–C(G_{ori})italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to achieve good performance on Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤T_{dow}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The nature of â€œpre-training and fine-tuningâ€ is to hope the fine-tuned graph model could approximate to Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–C(G_{ori})italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ):

FÎ¸âˆ—â†’Î¸#â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)â†’Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)â†’subscriptğ¹â†’superscriptğœƒsuperscriptğœƒ#subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta^{*}\rightarrow\theta^{\#}}(G_{ori})\rightarrow C(G_{ori})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â†’ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (2)

However, achieving this goal usually requires fine-tuning the graph model, which is not always efficient and needs many empirical tuning tricks. The tuning course may be even harder if the pre-trained model is ill-designed for the downstream task. In addition, we can not guarantee that fine-tuning the pre-trained model (i.e. Î¸âˆ—â†’Î¸#â†’superscriptğœƒsuperscriptğœƒ#\theta^{*}\rightarrow\theta^{\#}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) can always surpass training the model from scratch because the preserved knowledge may contribute negatively to the downstream task.

3.2 Perspective from Data Operation

Instead of the above model-level tricks, graph prompts provide a data-level alternative. Some prior works (Fang etÂ al., 2024; Sun etÂ al., 2023a) have initially proved that graph prompts can simulate any graph operations (e.g., deleting/adding nodes/edges/subgraphs, changing node features, etc). However, how effective of graph prompt is and why this works for the new task are still not yet answered. To answer these questions, we first explain our data operation perspective by a theorem as follows:

Theorem 1.

Let FÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒF_{\theta^{*}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a GNN model pre-trained on task Tpâ¢râ¢esubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’T_{pre}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_r italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with frozen parameters (Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT); let Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤T_{dow}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the downstream task and Cğ¶Citalic_C is an optimal function to Tdâ¢oâ¢wsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¤T_{dow}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given any graph Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{ori}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Câ¢(Gori)ğ¶subscriptğºoriC(G_{\text{ori}})italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denotes the optimal embedding vector to the downstream task (i.e. can be parsed to yield correct results for GorisubscriptğºoriG_{\text{ori}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the downstream task), then there always exists a bridge graph Gbâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{bri}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)=Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{bri})=C(G_{ori})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

A detailed proof of Theorem 1 can be seen in Appendix A.3.1, from which we can find that for any given graph Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{ori}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there always exists a bridge graph, say Gbâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{bri}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, making the following equation hold:

FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)=Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{bri})=C(G_{ori})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (3)

That means, without needing to tune the model, we can try to find a data operation method that translates Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{ori}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to Gbâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{bri}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the pre-trained model unchanged. Graph prompts can be treated as a learnable data operation framework to help us manipulate these graph data. In this way, we can significantly reduce the difficulty of traditional fine-tuning work, improve the performance on a new task (or even a new dataset), and further enhance the generalization of graph neural networks. With this perspective, our next question is: How difficult to find such a bridge graph using graph prompts?

3.3 Measuring the Difficulty of Finding Bridge Graphs via Graph Prompts

Graph prompts can be viewed as a type of graph transformation operator. For example, the simplest graph prompt is just adding a specific prompt token vector pÏ‰subscriptğ‘ğœ”p_{\omega}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to each node feature of the graph and then we can transform this graph GğºGitalic_G into a family of graphs {PÏ‰â¢(G)|Ï‰âˆˆâ„F}conditional-setsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºğœ”superscriptâ„ğ¹\{P_{\omega}(G)|\omega\in\mathbb{R}^{F}\}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) | italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, where PÏ‰â¢(G)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºP_{\omega}(G)italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) represents the output graph obtained by graph prompt on GğºGitalic_G. Once Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ is determined, the corresponding data transformation rule and unique output graph data are also defined. This family can be understood as the â€œtransformation spaceâ€ of graph GğºGitalic_G under prompt Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, denoted as DPâ¢(G)subscriptğ·ğ‘ƒğºD_{P}(G)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ). If the prompt operator maps the original graph GorisubscriptğºoriG_{\text{ori}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a bridge graph GbrisubscriptğºbriG_{\text{bri}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bri end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., Pâ¢(Gori)=Gbriğ‘ƒsubscriptğºorisubscriptğºbriP(G_{\text{ori}})=G_{\text{bri}}italic_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bri end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), then applying the pre-trained model FÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒF_{\theta^{*}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT yields FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Pâ¢(Gori))=FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gbri)subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒğ‘ƒsubscriptğºorisubscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºbriF_{\theta^{*}}(P(G_{\text{ori}}))=F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{\text{bri}})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bri end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which conforms to the downstream task. In this process, we achieve seamless alignment of upstream and downstream tasks solely through data transformation operators, without relying on tuning the modelâ€™s parameters.

Definition 1 (Bridge Set and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended Bridge Set).

The bridge set of a graph GğºGitalic_G is defined as:

BG={Gpâˆ£FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gp)=Câ¢(G)}subscriptğµğºconditional-setsubscriptğºğ‘subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ¶ğºB_{G}=\{G_{p}\mid F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{p})=C(G)\}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_C ( italic_G ) }

where FÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒF_{\theta^{*}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the frozen graph model from the pre-training task, and Cğ¶Citalic_C is the optimal function for the downstream task. The Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended bridge set of GğºGitalic_G is a relaxed version of the bridge set, which is defined as:

Ïµâ¢-â¢BG={Gpâˆ£Ïµ=â€–FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gp)âˆ’Câ¢(G)â€–â‰¤Ïµâˆ—}.italic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğºconditional-setsubscriptğºğ‘italic-Ïµnormsubscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ¶ğºsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}=\{G_{p}\mid\epsilon=\|F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{p})-C(G)\|\leq% \epsilon^{*}\}.italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_Ïµ = âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } .

Achieving a transformation exactly equivalent to Câ¢(G)ğ¶ğºC(G)italic_C ( italic_G ) is highly non-parametric and nonlinear. Finding the corresponding GbrisubscriptğºbriG_{\text{bri}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bri end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or even the bridge set for any GorisubscriptğºoriG_{\text{ori}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT involves solving complex, high-order nonlinear equations. This task becomes virtually impossible manually, especially if the pre-training method integrates multiple tasks or intricate mechanisms. Fortunately, graph prompts PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be viewed as parameterized fitting for these operators and they usually contain very lightweight parameters, which dramatically simplify the search space compared with manually designed strategies. The effectiveness of graph prompting methods hinges on their ability to approximate these operators closelyâ€”whether they can uniformly project GğºGitalic_G in the dataset into the bridge set BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, or at least map them into the extended bridge set with a small upper error bound Ïµâˆ—superscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

4 The Upper Bound of Data Operation Error via Graph Prompt

4.1 Upper Bound of the Error on A Single Graph

Here we aim to demonstrate that using graph prompts provided by frameworks such as GPF and All-in-One, denoted as parameterized operators PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with parameter Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰, can consistently project GğºGitalic_G into an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ has a uniform upper bound. This would initially validate the effectiveness of graph prompting methods in leveraging the potential of pre-trained models without compromising their expressive power. If GğºGitalic_G can be seamlessly projected into BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (for small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ), it would indicate excellent performance and full utilization of the modelâ€™s capabilities.

To this end, we first conduct a quantitative analysis of PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s graph transformation approximation ability on a single graph. With our proposed data operation perspective, we can reformulate the findings in Fang etÂ al. (2022) as follows:

Theorem 2.

Given a GPF-like prompt vector pÏ‰subscriptğ‘ğœ”p_{\omega}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not have any non-linear transformations, then there exists an optimal Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ for any input graph GğºGitalic_G such that PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆBGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºsubscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This theorem is proved by Fang etÂ al. (2022) but itâ€™s important to note that all GNN models employ non-linear transformations. According to the function approximation theorem for neural networks (Hornik etÂ al., 1989), the core of improving a modelâ€™s approximation and simulation ability lies in its non-linear components. Removing these non-linear parts would limit the model to approximating only linear transformations and functions. To demonstrate the effectiveness of graph prompt learning in real downstream tasks, we offer the following theorems further:

Theorem 3.

Given a GPF-like prompt vector pÏ‰subscriptğ‘ğœ”p_{\omega}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has non-linear function layers but the modelâ€™s weight matrix is row full-rank, then there exists an optimal Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ for any input graph GğºGitalic_G such that PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆBGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºsubscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Theorem 4.

Given the All-in-One-like prompt graph Sâ¢GÏ‰ğ‘†subscriptğºğœ”SG_{\omega}italic_S italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not have any non-linear transformations, or has non-linear layers but the modelâ€™s weight matrix is row full-rank, then there exists an optimal Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ for any input graph GğºGitalic_G such that PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆBGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºsubscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Theorems 3 and 4 are proved in Appendix A.3.2. Although weâ€™ve only added the row full-rank condition, these two theorems significantly expand the applicability of Theorem 2. According to Pennington & Worah (2017), well-trained models mostly contain full-rank matrices, which can be easily guaranteed by some tricks like orthogonal initialization, He initialization, etc. Raghu etÂ al. (2017) also find that a full-rank parameter matrix in the model usually indicates stronger expressiveness. Intuitively, a weight matrix in the graph model usually indicates how to project the input graph into some latent embedding for the downstream task. According to the basic knowledge of linear algebra, when the weight matrix is row full-rank, we can always restore the input from the output. That means we can always find an appropriate input format to meet various downstream requirements. Therefore, from a practical empirical perspective, we can assume that in most cases, both GPF-like and All-in-One-like frameworks can achieve seamless projection of GğºGitalic_G into BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, demonstrating the effectiveness and rationality of graph prompting.

For the cases where weight matrices are not full-rank, we have found that the error value (Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ) of the extended bridge set (Ïµâˆ’BGitalic-Ïµsubscriptğµğº\epsilon-B_{G}italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), into which the prompting framework can map GğºGitalic_G, is positively correlated with the distance of the graph model parameter matrix from being full-rank. However, a consistent upper bound does exist for the error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ of the extended bridge set when the matrix rank is determined. This means that even in some extreme cases, graph prompt learning can still guarantee a certain level of performance without experiencing extremely unexpectedly poor results:

Theorem 5.

For a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, assume at least one layerâ€™s parameter matrix is not full rank, for GPF or All-in-One prompt, there exists an upper bound of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ such that for any input graph GğºGitalic_G, there exists an optimal Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ where PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆÏµâ¢-â¢BGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºitalic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with Ïµâ‰¤Î¼â¢(Î¸âˆ—)â‹…Î»â¢(G)italic-Ïµâ‹…ğœ‡superscriptğœƒğœ†ğº\epsilon\leq\mu(\theta^{*})\cdot\lambda(G)italic_Ïµ â‰¤ italic_Î¼ ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‹… italic_Î» ( italic_G ), where Î¼â¢(Î¸âˆ—)ğœ‡superscriptğœƒ\mu(\theta^{*})italic_Î¼ ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Î»â¢(G)ğœ†ğº\lambda(G)italic_Î» ( italic_G ) correspond to the model and graph GğºGitalic_G, respectively.

Theorem 5 is proved in Appendix A.3.3, where the upper bound of the error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ can be further expressed as follows:

Î¼â¢(Î¸âˆ—)â¢Î»â¢(G)=sinâ¡(Î¦/2)â¢â€–Câ¢(G)â€–ğœ‡superscriptğœƒğœ†ğºÎ¦2normğ¶ğº\mu(\theta^{*})\lambda(G)=\sin(\Phi/2)\|C(G)\|italic_Î¼ ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_Î» ( italic_G ) = roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ) âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ (4)

The upper bound has two terms, one part is related to the model because sinâ¡(Î¦/2)Î¦2\sin(\Phi/2)roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ) can be treated as a measurement of the modelâ€™s expressiveness, the details of which can be seen in Appendix A.3.3. The other part is related to â€–Câ¢(G)â€–normğ¶ğº\|C(G)\|âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥. Since the graph prompt aims to approximate GğºGitalic_G with PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–P_{\omega}(G_{ori})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), that means the error is also related to the prompt design. In this way, we in theory confirm the intuitional findings by Sun etÂ al. (2023a) as mentioned in our motivation section.

The upper bound of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ given in Theorem 5 reveals the potential distortion of BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s shape when the matrix is not full-rank and the modelâ€™s expressive power is insufficient. This can lead to an increased distance between BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the transformation domain DPâ¢(G)subscriptğ·ğ‘ƒğºD_{P}(G)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) (see this term in section 3.3) of GPF or All-in-One prompts. To confirm this judgment, we conducted a quantitative analysis using numerical methods for the case of non-full rank matrices. We make the graph model weight matrix be not full-rank (with rank nâˆ’rğ‘›ğ‘Ÿn-ritalic_n - italic_r where nğ‘›nitalic_n is the full rank number and r=0,â‹¯â¢nğ‘Ÿ0â‹¯ğ‘›r=0,\cdots nitalic_r = 0 , â‹¯ italic_n) and use the distance between the embedding vectors of PÏ‰â¢(G)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºP_{\omega}(G)italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) and Câ¢(G)ğ¶ğºC(G)italic_C ( italic_G ) as the loss function. We applied stochastic gradient descent with a learning rate of 0.0001 to optimize Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ until convergence. To avoid local optima, we repeated the process multiple times with different initializations for each graph. The results are shown in Figure 1, where the vertical axis is the empirical max Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ of the extended BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the horizontal axis is rğ‘Ÿritalic_r where r=0,1,2,â‹¯,9,10ğ‘Ÿ012â‹¯910r=0,1,2,\cdots,9,10italic_r = 0 , 1 , 2 , â‹¯ , 9 , 10, making the matrix rank become nâˆ’rğ‘›ğ‘Ÿn-ritalic_n - italic_r. From Figure 1 we can find that with the increase of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, the rank of the model matrix becomes lower, making the model expressiveness worse and then leading to a larger error bound. Besides, more advanced graph prompts (e.g., GPF-Plus, All-in-One, and All-in-One-Plus) generally have a lower bound than the naive one (e.g., GPF).

4.2 Extend the Error Bound Discussion to A Batch of Graphs

In Sections 3 and 4.1, we have proved that graph prompting frameworks can indeed fit graph transformation operators given a single graph, thereby exploiting model capabilities. However, in other cases, we often train the model via a batch of graphs and seek to find better performance over the whole graph dataset. Correspondingly, we should aspire to transform each graph GğºGitalic_G in the downstream dataset into its corresponding BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Ïµâ¢-â¢BGitalic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğº\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (for small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ). If such a uniform upper bound Ïµâˆ—superscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT exists, it would theoretically validate the excellent performance of graph prompting in general downstream tasks, confirming the rational utilization of powerful upstream models.

For a batch of graphs, the complexity and information contained in the graph prompt become particularly important. For instance, the increased number of prompt vectors in GPF (a.k.a GPF-Plus) and the selection of a larger size of the prompt graph in All-in-One greatly expand the transformation space of graph GğºGitalic_G under prompt Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P (see DPâ¢(â‹…)subscriptğ·ğ‘ƒâ‹…D_{P}(\cdot)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) in section 3.3). A larger transformation space corresponds to a smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ upper bound. In our theoretical analysis, we found that when the prompt takes an overly simple form, the capability of prompt learning is limited. This manifests as a theoretical lower bound of the bridge set extension as suggested in Theorem 6:

Theorem 6.

For a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for GPF with a single prompt vector or All-in-One with a single-token graph prompt, given a batch of graphs ğ’¢={G1,â‹¯,Gi,â‹¯,Gn}ğ’¢subscriptğº1â‹¯subscriptğºğ‘–â‹¯subscriptğºğ‘›\mathcal{G}=\{G_{1},\cdots,G_{i},\cdots,G_{n}\}caligraphic_G = { italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, the root mean squared error (RMSE) over {Ïµ1,â‹¯,Ïµn}subscriptitalic-Ïµ1â‹¯subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›\{\epsilon_{1},\cdots,\epsilon_{n}\}{ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } has a lower bound Ïµosuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘œ\epsilon^{o}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Râ¢Mâ¢Sâ¢Eâ¢(Ïµ1,â‹¯,Ïµn)â‰¥Ïµoğ‘…ğ‘€ğ‘†ğ¸subscriptitalic-Ïµ1â‹¯subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘›superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘œRMSE(\epsilon_{1},\cdots,\epsilon_{n})\geq\epsilon^{o}italic_R italic_M italic_S italic_E ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Theorem 6 is proved in Appendix A.3.4 and we also give the detailed formulation of Ïµosuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘œ\epsilon^{o}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the proof, from which we can find that Ïµosuperscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘œ\epsilon^{o}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is related to graph data and the prompt token. This indicates that when the downstream task dataset is relatively large, we must correspondingly increase the transformation space of the prompt to better utilize the modelâ€™s capabilities, which also aligns with existing empirical observations (Liu etÂ al., 2021). Then our next question is: With the increase of graphs, how does graph prompt complexity increase with their error bound increased?

Intuitively, a good graph prompt should not increase its complexity faster than the growth of the dataset because in that case the effectiveness of prompt learning in practical applications would be significantly compromised. Fortunately, we found that for relatively large datasets, the scale of prompts required for prompt learning is highly controllable with the number of needed tokens for the prompt almost constant, far from the increase of graphs. This explains why even with relatively large downstream datasets, as reflected in Sun etÂ al. (2023a), empirical results using medium-scale prompts can still achieve excellent outcomes. Compared to fine-tuning the entire model parameters, Theorem 7 (see the proof in Appendix A.3.4) indicates why graph prompting can achieve comparable or even better results with less parameter adjustment scale:

Theorem 7.

Given a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, an All-in-One-like graph prompt with multiple prompt tokens, and a dataset ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G with Mğ‘€Mitalic_M graphs, there exists an upper bound denoted by Ïµâˆ—superscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, making an optimal PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that âˆ€Giâˆˆğ’¢,PÏ‰â¢(Gi)âˆˆÏµiâ¢-â¢BGiformulae-sequencefor-allsubscriptğºğ‘–ğ’¢subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–-subscriptğµsubscriptğºğ‘–\forall G_{i}\in\mathcal{G},P_{\omega}(G_{i})\in\epsilon_{i}\text{-}B_{G_{i}}âˆ€ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_G , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and âˆ‘i=1MÏµi2/Mâ‰¤Ïµâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–2ğ‘€superscriptitalic-Ïµ\sqrt{\sum^{M}_{i=1}\epsilon_{i}^{2}/M}\leq\epsilon^{*}square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_M end_ARG â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Ïµâˆ—superscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be further calculated as follows:

Ïµâˆ—=âˆ‘i=k+1MÎ»i/Msuperscriptitalic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘€subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘€\epsilon^{*}=\sqrt{\sum_{i=k+1}^{M}\lambda_{i}/M}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_M end_ARG (5)

Here for the Mğ‘€Mitalic_M graphs in ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G, we first construct an optimal solution matrix according to function Cğ¶Citalic_C, thus have: S=[Câ¢(G1),â€¦,Câ¢(GM)]ğ‘†ğ¶subscriptğº1â€¦ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘€S=[C(G_{1}),\ldots,C(G_{M})]italic_S = [ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]. Then V=SâŠ¤â¢Sâˆˆâ„MÃ—Mğ‘‰superscriptğ‘†topğ‘†superscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘€V=S^{\top}S\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times M}italic_V = italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M Ã— italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the correlation matrix of downstream solutions upon such graph dataset. The eigenvalues of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V sorted by the descending order can be denoted as {Î»1,â‹¯,Î»M}subscriptğœ†1â‹¯subscriptğœ†ğ‘€\{\lambda_{1},\cdots,\lambda_{M}\}{ italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Then the upper bound Ïµâˆ—superscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be treated as the mean square over the smallest Mâˆ’kğ‘€ğ‘˜M-kitalic_M - italic_k eigenvalues. In practice, the eigenvalues of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V in datasets often exhibit an exponential decay (Johnstone, 2001). This explains the rapid decrease in error rate as kğ‘˜kitalic_k increases, proving that prompts are not only effective but also efficient. With the increasing number of graphs Mğ‘€Mitalic_M in the dataset, the largest kğ‘˜kitalic_k (kâ‰ªMmuch-less-thanğ‘˜ğ‘€k\ll Mitalic_k â‰ª italic_M) eigenvalues can almost explain most of the matrix, which means using small-scaled prompt tokens can achieve reasonably accurate results. This finding is also consistent with many existing empirical researches (Liu etÂ al., 2023; Sun etÂ al., 2023a; Wang etÂ al., 2024; Zhu etÂ al., 2024a; Zi etÂ al., 2024).

4.3 Value Distribution of the Data Operation Error with Graph Prompt

In the previous sections, we established a theoretical upper bound of Ïµâ‰¤Ïµâˆ—italic-Ïµsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon\leq\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ â‰¤ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, allowing the graph prompt PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to map a given graph GğºGitalic_G into the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT range. However, the conditions to reach this upper bound are often difficult to meet, making the theoretical upper bound usually correspond to some corner cases which may be not that practical in processing empirical experimental analysis. To offer stronger practical guidance for researchersâ€™ general experimental purposes, the value distribution of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ (a.k.a â€œerror rangeâ€), comes to our next point of interest. The error range analysis indicates a quantitative degree of the bridge set extension, which includes estimating the mean, and variance, and finding the approximate distribution pattern.

Definition 2 (Graph Embedding Residual Vector).

Consider a graph model with Leaky-Relu as their activation function, we denote the graph embedding residual vector as ğ›ƒâˆˆâ„1Ã—Fğ›ƒsuperscriptâ„1ğ¹\bm{\beta}\in\mathbb{R}^{1\times F}bold_italic_Î² âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 Ã— italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where Fğ¹Fitalic_F is the graph embedding dimensions. Each entry of ğ›ƒğ›ƒ\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² is related to the bridge graph embedding, graph prompt, and the original graph, which is mathematically defined as follows:

[ğœ·]j=âˆ‘iâˆ’Î±kâ¢wiâ¢viâ¢jsubscriptdelimited-[]ğœ·ğ‘—subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—[\bm{\beta}]_{j}=\sum_{i}-\alpha^{k}w_{i}v_{ij}[ bold_italic_Î² ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (6)

where Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is the parameter of Leaky-Relu; viâ¢jsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—v_{ij}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th element in the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th node embedding of the bridge graph Gbâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{bri}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the weight of the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th node for graph pooling (e.g., summation graph pooling means for any node iğ‘–iitalic_i in Gbâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{bri}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have wi=1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–1w_{i}=1italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1); kğ‘˜kitalic_k can be either 00 or âˆ’11-1- 1 and depends on the original graph, graph prompt, and the bridge graph, the details of which can be seen in Appendix 5. Here, we assume that ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² should follow an i.i.d. normal distribution with mean 0 and variance cğ‘citalic_c (we carefully discuss the rationality of this assumption in Appendix 5): ğœ·âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,câ¢In)similar-toğœ·ğ’©0ğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ‘›\bm{\beta}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,cI_{n})bold_italic_Î² âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_c italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where Insubscriptğ¼ğ‘›I_{n}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times nitalic_n Ã— italic_n identity matrix and cğ‘citalic_c is a positive constant. Then we theoretically find that Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ conforms to the Chi distribution (Ï‡ksubscriptğœ’ğ‘˜\chi_{k}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT):

Theorem 8.

Given a GCN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the last layer parameter matrix having rank Fâˆ’rğ¹ğ‘ŸF-ritalic_F - italic_r (Fğ¹Fitalic_F is the graph embedding dimension, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is the rank lost), an input graph GğºGitalic_G, for the optimal Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰, PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆÏµâ¢-â¢BGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºitalic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the Graph Embedding Residuals follow the i.i.d. normal distribution, then Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ follows a Chi distribution Ï‡rsubscriptğœ’ğ‘Ÿ\chi_{r}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with rğ‘Ÿritalic_r free variables.

We give the proof of Theorem 8 in Appendix A.3.5. In the practical settings, the distribution of graph residual terms may slightly diverge from i.i.d. normal distribution, making the real distribution of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ a little different from standard Ï‡ksubscriptğœ’ğ‘˜\chi_{k}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Besides, there is also a theoretical upper bound Ïµâˆ—superscriptitalic-Ïµ\epsilon^{*}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, making the real distribution of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ more like a truncated Ï‡ksubscriptğœ’ğ‘˜\chi_{k}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The statistical measures of this distribution can be easily obtained as follows:

Corollary 1 (Statistical Measures and Confidence Values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ).

The mean of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ is câ¢2â¢Î“â¢((r+1)/2)Î“â¢(r/2)ğ‘2Î“ğ‘Ÿ12Î“ğ‘Ÿ2c\sqrt{2}\frac{\Gamma((r+1)/2)}{\Gamma(r/2)}italic_c square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG roman_Î“ ( ( italic_r + 1 ) / 2 ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_Î“ ( italic_r / 2 ) end_ARG, the variance is c2â¢(râˆ’2â¢[Î“â¢((r+1)/2)]2[Î“â¢(r/2)]2)superscriptğ‘2ğ‘Ÿ2superscriptdelimited-[]Î“ğ‘Ÿ122superscriptdelimited-[]Î“ğ‘Ÿ22c^{2}\left(r-2\frac{[\Gamma((r+1)/2)]^{2}}{[\Gamma(r/2)]^{2}}\right)italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r - 2 divide start_ARG [ roman_Î“ ( ( italic_r + 1 ) / 2 ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG [ roman_Î“ ( italic_r / 2 ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ), and confidence values can be obtained through CÏ‡r,psuperscriptsubscriptğ¶ğœ’ğ‘Ÿğ‘C_{\chi}^{r,p}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‡ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r , italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using numerical methods or table lookup, where c is the scaling factor compared to the standard distribution, and r is the number of dimensions lost compared to a full-rank matrix.

To further confirm our theoretical findings, we compare the real-world distribution of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ with 4 commonly used distribution patterns (Chi, Chi-square, Exponential, and Gamma). Figure 2 presents the fitting results and Table 1 shows the pğ‘pitalic_p-value significance, from which we can see that the Chi distribution provides the best approximation within a non-extreme range of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ.

4.4 Extend the Discussion from Linear Models to Non-linear Models

While our previous analysis focused on GCN or linear aggregation models that can be represented in the form of â€œdiffusion matricesâ€, many advanced models utilizing attention mechanisms exhibit distinctly different characteristics. Their aggregation methods involve the computation of attention matrices, which in turn depend on the node feature vectors of GğºGitalic_G. This can be considered as a non-linear model w.r.t GğºGitalic_Gâ€™s feature matrix. In our analysis, we use Graph Attention Networks (GAT) as an exemplar, as the attention mechanism in GAT is a common component in many non-linear models. Fortunately, the guarantees provided by our theorems do not differ significantly for these models. This indicates that even as models become more non-linear and complex, graph prompting can still effectively harness the powerful capabilities of pre-trained models:

Theorem 9.

Let FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a GAT model. If any layer of the model has a full row rank parameter matrix, then for the All-in-One prompting framework, for any input graph G, there exists an optimal Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ such that PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆBGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºsubscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. When the parameter matrix is not full rank, there is an upper bound Î¼â¢(Î¸)â‹…Î»â¢(G)â‹…ğœ‡ğœƒğœ†ğº\mu(\theta)\cdot\lambda(G)italic_Î¼ ( italic_Î¸ ) â‹… italic_Î» ( italic_G ) making PÏ‰â¢(G)âˆˆÏµâ¢-â¢BGsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”ğºitalic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğºP_{\omega}(G)\in\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ïµâ‰¤Î¼â¢(Î¸)â‹…Î»â¢(G)italic-Ïµâ‹…ğœ‡ğœƒğœ†ğº\epsilon\leq\mu(\theta)\cdot\lambda(G)italic_Ïµ â‰¤ italic_Î¼ ( italic_Î¸ ) â‹… italic_Î» ( italic_G ).

We give a detailed proof in Appendix A.3.6. The above theorem demonstrates the robustness of graph prompting methods across different types of GNN architectures, including those with non-linear attention mechanisms. The consistency of these results with our earlier findings for linear models suggests that the fundamental principles of graph prompting remain effective even as we move towards more complex and non-linear model architectures.

5 Experiments

5.1 Experimental Settings

Data Preparation: We first confirm our theoretical findings on synthetic datasets because these datasets offer controlled environments, allowing us to isolate specific variables and study their impacts. We generate these datasets by defining the dimension of graph feature vector (Fğ¹Fitalic_F), average of graph node numbers (Naâ¢vâ¢gsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”N_{avg}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_v italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), average of graph edge numbers (Eaâ¢vâ¢gsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”E_{avg}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_v italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and number of graphs in the dataset (Mğ‘€Mitalic_M). These parameters characterize both individual graphs and the entire dataset, facilitating our study of the relationship between these features and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ. We further conduct the experiments on the real-world dataset in Appendix B, from which we can find similar observations.

Model Settings: We utilize two GNN frameworks: GCN (representing linear models) and GAT (representing non-linear models). We limit our experiments to these two models as other models follow similar patterns. Unless otherwise specified, we use a 3-layer GNN with Leaky-ReLU activation function and feature dimension F=25ğ¹25F=25italic_F = 25. For full-rank matrix studies, we ensure each layerâ€™s matrix is full-rank (selected after pre-training). For non-full-rank matrix studies, we set the rank loss to 5 by default. The default ReadOut method is mean pooling.

Training: In the graph prompting training process, we perform gradient descent on the parameters Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ of the graph prompt PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the Adam optimizer. We use a learning rate of 1Ã—10âˆ’41superscript1041\times 10^{-4}1 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and weight decay of 5Ã—10âˆ’55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}5 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We implement an early stopping mechanism with a maximum of 2,000 epochs by default. Our loss function is defined as â€–FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gp)âˆ’Câ¢(G)â€–normsubscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ¶ğº\|F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{p})-C(G)\|âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ for single-graph tasks, and âˆ‘Gâˆˆğ’¢â€–FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gp)âˆ’Câ¢(G)â€–2/Msubscriptğºğ’¢superscriptnormsubscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ¶ğº2ğ‘€\sqrt{\sum_{G\in\mathcal{G}}\|F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{p})-C(G)\|^{2}/M}square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G âˆˆ caligraphic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_M end_ARG for multi-graph tasks where Gpsubscriptğºğ‘G_{p}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the combined graph with GğºGitalic_G and graph prompt, and Câ¢(G)ğ¶ğºC(G)italic_C ( italic_G ) means an optimal function to the downstream task, which is not accessible without a specific task. Since the ultimate purpose of graph prompting is to approximate graph operation, we here treat Câ¢(â‹…)ğ¶â‹…C(\cdot)italic_C ( â‹… ) as various graph data permutations such as adding/deleting nodes, adding/deleting/changing edges, and transforming features of a given graph GğºGitalic_G. Then we wish to see how well the graph prompt reaches Câ¢(G)ğ¶ğºC(G)italic_C ( italic_G ) by manipulating graph data with a graph prompt. For more detailed experimental settings, please check in the Appendix C.

5.2 On mapping to BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with single graph

According to Theorems 3, 4, and 9, error-free projection can be achieved in full-rank situations. Here we investigate convergence properties with a maximum of 5,000 epochs. Figure 3 presents the results for GPF and All-in-One prompts with GCN and GAT, respectively. From the results we can find that for single-graph, full-rank matrix scenarios, both GPF and All-in-one approaches show loss converging to zero, which is consistent with our theoretical findings.

5.3 On mapping to Ïµâ¢-â¢BGitalic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğº\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with single graph

Theorem 5 states that in non-full-rank situations, there exists an upper bound on the error. Here we extensively examine the relationship between various parameters and the error upper bounds in the context of non-full-rank matrices given a single graph. Since showing this upper bound in practice is usually intractable, we fix all other parameters and employ five pre-trained models. For each fixed pre-trained model, we conduct experiments and repeat each experiment 30 times. Then we take the maximum loss from these repetitions as the approximation to the upper bound.

Subsequently, we calculate the mean and standard deviation of these upper bounds to generate plots. The parameters of interest include rank loss (as shown in Figure 1 in section 4.1), node feature dimension (Figure 4a), graph size (Figure 4b), and model layer number (Figure 4c). Intuitively, with the increase of data complexity (e.g., larger features and graph size), the upper bound becomes larger in general. As the graph model becomes more complicated (e.g., layer number increase), the projected space becomes larger making the error bound intend to be smaller. When weight rank declines, the modelâ€™s capacity intends to poor results, making the error bound increase. More advanced graph prompts (e.g., All-in-One) usually have a lower error bound than the naive one (e.g., GPF). These observations can be naturally inferred from our theoretical analysis in section 4.1.

5.4 On mapping to Ïµâ¢-â¢BGitalic-Ïµ-subscriptğµğº\epsilon\text{-}B_{G}italic_Ïµ - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with multiple graphs

Theorem 6 discusses a lower bound on the RMSE over the errors on multiple graphs with a single prompt token. In this section, we conducted experiments on the number of graphs in the dataset w.r.t the empirical minimum error. As shown in Figure 5a, the minimum error shows an upward trend and then tends to saturate, which is highly consistent with the findings in Theorem 6.

Theorem 7 suggests that for the graph prompt with multiple tokens and multiple graphs, a small kğ‘˜kitalic_k tokens is sufficient to achieve good performance. In particular, we wish to see how the error (loss) changes as Mğ‘€Mitalic_M (number of graphs) increases while kğ‘˜kitalic_k remains fixed, and its counterpart case: how does the error change as kğ‘˜kitalic_k increases while Mğ‘€Mitalic_M remains fixed? Here we explored the relationship between the number of prompt tokens, the number of graphs in the dataset, and the error. We present experimental results in Figure 5b and Figure 5c, which indicate two surfaces. From these figures we can find that both GPF and All-in-One show similar effects: when the number of prompt tokens exceeds 10101010, the error becomes relatively small. As the number of prompt tokens increases further, the loss does not significantly decrease. Similarly, when the number of graphs increases and the number of prompt tokens is large, the decrease in error is also not that obvious.

6 Conclusion

This paper addresses the theoretical gap in graph prompting by introducing a comprehensive framework from a data operation perspective. We introduced the concepts of â€œbridge setsâ€ and â€œÏµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-extended bridge setsâ€ to formally demonstrate that graph prompts can approximate graph transformation operators, effectively bridging pre-trained models with downstream tasks without retraining. Our contributions are threefold: first, we established guarantee theorems confirming that graph prompts can simulate various graph data operations, explaining their effectiveness in aligning upstream and downstream tasks. Second, we derived upper bounds on the approximation errors introduced by graph prompts for both individual graphs and batches of graphs, highlighting how factors like model rank and prompt complexity influence these errors. Third, we analyzed the distribution of these errors and extended our theoretical findings from linear models like GCNs to non-linear models such as GATs, showcasing the robustness of graph prompting across different architectures. Our extensive experiments validate these theoretical results and confirm their practical implications, demonstrating that graph prompts can effectively leverage pre-trained models in various settings. By providing solid theoretical foundations, our work not only explains why graph prompts work but also guides the design of more effective prompting techniques. This empowers researchers and practitioners to utilize graph prompts with greater confidence, potentially leading to more efficient and generalized graph neural network models across diverse applications.

References

  • Ben-Tal & Nemirovski (2001) Aharon Ben-Tal and Arkadi Nemirovski. Lectures on modern convex optimization: analysis, algorithms, and engineering applications. SIAM, 2001.
  • Boyd & Vandenberghe (2004) Stephen Boyd and Lieven Vandenberghe. Convex optimization. Cambridge university press, 2004.
  • Chen etÂ al. (2024) XiÂ Chen, Siwei Zhang, Yun Xiong, Xixi Wu, Jiawei Zhang, Xiangguo Sun, Yao Zhang, Yinglong Zhao, and Yulin Kang. Prompt learning on temporal interaction graphs. arXiv:2402.06326, 2024.
  • Diao etÂ al. (2022) Cameron Diao, Kaixiong Zhou, Zirui Liu, Xiao Huang, and Xia Hu. Molcpt: Molecule continuous prompt tuning to generalize molecular representation learning. arXiv preprint arXiv:2212.10614, 2022.
  • Fang etÂ al. (2022) Mingchen Fang, Yuan Zhang, KeÂ Jiang, Kaiqi Zhao, Qingyun Xue, Beilun Zheng, Guan Qin, and Xinwang Zhang. Graph prompt learning: Towards generalization of graph neural networks for out-of-distribution data. In Proceedings of the 31st ACM International Conference on Information & Knowledge Management, pp.Â  442â€“452, 2022.

Appendix

The appendix of this paper is organized as follows: Appendix A presents the detailed theoretical content on the main findings in the paper. In order to reduce the bar of reading this content, we first give some preliminaries and definitions in Appendix A.1, followed by fundamental lemmas (Appendix A.2) that will be used to prove our theorems. In Appendix A.3, we carefully prove the theorems in the main body of this paper, followed by a further mathematical discussion in Appendix A.4. Beyond theoretical analysis, Appendix B presents additional experimental results on the real-world datasets, which have similar observations to the main experiments in the paper. Appendix C introduces more details on the settings of the experiment.

Appendix A Theoretical Analysis And Proofs

Reading Guideline: Appendix A â€œTheoretical Results and Proofsâ€ is divided into four subsections:

  • â€¢

    A.1 Definitions and Preliminaries: Readers are advised to initially skip this subsection. It serves as a reference for unfamiliar terms encountered later in the text.

  • â€¢

    A.2 Fundamental Lemmas: These properties are essential components for proving the main theorems. We will clearly express what each lemma demonstrates. Readers are recommended to refer to this subsection when encountering these lemmas while reading the theorem proofs.

  • â€¢

    A.3 Detailed Proofs of Main Theorems: This subsection is recommended as the primary focus for readers. It contains the core ideas behind why prompts work, even though some lemmas may be required for complete understanding.

  • â€¢

    A.4 Additional Mathematical Lemmas: This subsection includes purely mathematical lemmas encountered during the proofs in A.2 or A.3. These lemmas are not directly related to GNN models or prompts. Readers are advised to review this subsection after reading the previous content.

A.1 Preliminaries And Definitions

A.1.1 Preliminaries

Preliminary 1 (GCN and GAT).

Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) Kipf & Welling (2016) perform convolution operations on graph-structured data by aggregating feature information from a nodeâ€™s neighbors. The recursive update rule for a GCN layer is:

ğ‡(l+1)=Ïƒâ¢(ğ€~â¢ğ‡(l)â¢ğ–(l)),superscriptğ‡ğ‘™1ğœ~ğ€superscriptğ‡ğ‘™superscriptğ–ğ‘™\mathbf{H}^{(l+1)}=\sigma\left(\tilde{\mathbf{A}}\mathbf{H}^{(l)}\mathbf{W}^{(% l)}\right),bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (7)

where ğ€~=ğƒâˆ’1/2â¢ğ€ğƒâˆ’1/2~ğ€superscriptğƒ12superscriptğ€ğƒ12\tilde{\mathbf{A}}=\mathbf{D}^{-1/2}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{D}^{-1/2}over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG = bold_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_AD start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the normalized adjacency matrix, ğ‡(l)superscriptğ‡ğ‘™\mathbf{H}^{(l)}bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the node feature matrix at layer lğ‘™litalic_l, ğ–(l)superscriptğ–ğ‘™\mathbf{W}^{(l)}bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the learnable weight matrix, and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ is a nonlinear activation function.

Graph Attention Networks (GAT) VeliÄkoviÄ‡ etÂ al. (2017) enhance GCNs by introducing attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of neighboring nodes during aggregation. In the simplest form of self-attention, the attention coefficient between node iğ‘–iitalic_i and node jğ‘—jitalic_j is based on the inner product of their feature vectors:

eiâ¢jsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle e_{ij}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğ—iâŠ¤â¢ğ—j,absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–topsubscriptğ—ğ‘—\displaystyle=\mathbf{X}_{i}^{\top}\mathbf{X}_{j},= bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (8)
Î±iâ¢jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\alpha_{ij}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =expâ¡(eiâ¢j)âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’©â¢(i)expâ¡(eiâ¢k),absentsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜ğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\frac{\exp(e_{ij})}{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}(i)}\exp(e_{ik})},= divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k âˆˆ caligraphic_N ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , (9)
ğ‡i(l+1)superscriptsubscriptğ‡ğ‘–ğ‘™1\displaystyle\mathbf{H}_{i}^{(l+1)}bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =Ïƒâ¢(âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’©â¢(i)Î±iâ¢jâ¢ğ‡j(l)â¢ğ–(l)),absentğœsubscriptğ‘—ğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‡ğ‘—ğ‘™superscriptğ–ğ‘™\displaystyle=\sigma\left(\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}(i)}\alpha_{ij}\mathbf{H}_{j}^{% (l)}\mathbf{W}^{(l)}\right),= italic_Ïƒ ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ caligraphic_N ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (10)

where ğ’©â¢(i)ğ’©ğ‘–\mathcal{N}(i)caligraphic_N ( italic_i ) denotes the neighbors of node iğ‘–iitalic_i, Î±iâ¢jsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘—\alpha_{ij}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the normalized attention coefficient, and ğ–(l)superscriptğ–ğ‘™\mathbf{W}^{(l)}bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the learnable weight matrix at layer lğ‘™litalic_l. This mechanism allows the model to focus on the most relevant neighbors when updating node representations.

Preliminary 2 (Pre-training and Fine-tuning vs Pre-training and Prompt).

Pre-training and Fine-tuning Zhu etÂ al. (2021)involves two stages: first, a model is pre-trained on a large dataset to learn general representations, and then it is fine-tuned on a specific downstream task.

Formally, let FÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒF_{\theta^{*}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the pre-trained model and Câ¢(â‹…)ğ¶â‹…C(\cdot)italic_C ( â‹… ) be the optimal mapping function that maps the original graph to the embedding vector of the downstream task (i.e., can be parsed to yield correct results for Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{o}riitalic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_i in the downstream task)

Fine-tuning aims to adjust the model parameters from Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to Î¸#superscriptğœƒ#\theta^{\#}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT so that:

FÎ¸âˆ—â†’Î¸#â¢(Gori)â‰ˆCâ¢(Gori).subscriptğ¹â†’superscriptğœƒsuperscriptğœƒ#subscriptğºoriğ¶subscriptğºoriF_{\theta^{*}\rightarrow\theta^{\#}}(G_{\text{ori}})\approx C(G_{\text{ori}}).italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT # end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (11)

Pre-training and Prompting keeps the pre-trained model parameters fixed and instead modifies the input data to bridge the pre-training and downstream tasks. Specifically, it seeks a transformation from the original graph GorisubscriptğºoriG_{\text{ori}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a prompt-enhanced graph GbrisubscriptğºbriG_{\text{bri}}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bri end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that:

FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gbri)=Câ¢(Gori).subscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºbriğ¶subscriptğºoriF_{\theta^{*}}(G_{\text{bri}})=C(G_{\text{ori}}).italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bri end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ori end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (12)

This approach leverages the frozen pre-trained model by adapting the input data through graph prompts, eliminating the need to fine-tune the model parameters.

Preliminary 3 (GPF and All-in-One).

Graph Prompt Frameworks introduce learnable modifications to input graphs to enhance the performance of frozen pre-trained GNNs on downstream tasks. Two primary frameworks are prompt token vectors like GPF/GPF-Plus Fang etÂ al. (2022) and prompt subgraph like All-in-One Sun etÂ al. (2023a).

GPF (Graph Prompt Feature) adds a prompt vector to each nodeâ€™s feature vectors. Let ğ={p}ğğ‘\bm{\omega}=\{p\}bold_italic_Ï‰ = { italic_p }, pâˆˆâ„FÃ—1ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ¹1p\in\mathbb{R}^{F\times 1}italic_p âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F Ã— 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the learnable prompt vector, then the updated node features are:

[ğ—Ï‰]i=ğ—i+psubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ—ğœ”ğ‘–subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ‘[\mathbf{X}_{\omega}]_{i}=\mathbf{X}_{i}+p[ bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_p (13)

The original graph G=(ğ—,ğ€)ğºğ—ğ€G=(\mathbf{X},\mathbf{A})italic_G = ( bold_X , bold_A ) becomes the prompt-enhanced graph GÏ‰=(ğ—Ï‰,ğ€)subscriptğºğœ”subscriptğ—ğœ”ğ€G_{\omega}=(\mathbf{X}_{\omega},\mathbf{A})italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_A ).
