where R0âŠ¤=ğ°â¢R(n)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…0topğ°superscriptğ‘…ğ‘›R_{0}^{\top}=\mathbf{w}R^{(n)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_w italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Î»=ğ°âŠ¤â¢ğœğœ†superscriptğ°topğœ\lambda=\mathbf{w}^{\top}\mathbf{c}italic_Î» = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_c (Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0), since ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p spans â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we know that FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))=R0âŠ¤+Î»â¢ğ©âŠ¤subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘…0topğœ†superscriptğ©topF_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))=R_{0}^{\top}+\lambda\mathbf{p}^{\top}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î» bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a surjective mapping from the range of Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ to â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Meanwhile, FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta}(G_{bri})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a fixed vector in â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

By the surjective property, there must exist an Ï‰0subscriptğœ”0\omega_{0}italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that:

FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰0â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))=FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢iâ¢dâ¢gâ¢e)=Câ¢(G)subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ”0subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ¶ğºF_{\theta}(P_{\omega_{0}}(G_{ori}))=F_{\theta}(G_{bridge})=C(G)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i italic_d italic_g italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_C ( italic_G )

This completes the proof. âˆ

A.3.3 On Error Upper Bound Analysis of Mapping to Bridge Set at Single Graph Level

Proof of Theorems 5

Proof.

(Prompt Error Upper Bound on Single Graph With GCN model with layers containing non-linear functions and possibly non-full rank matrices)

Consider the optimal Ï‰0subscriptğœ”0\omega_{0}italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the transformed graph PÏ‰0â¢(G)âˆˆÏµsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ”0ğºitalic-ÏµP_{\omega_{0}}(G)\in\epsilonitalic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆˆ italic_Ïµ-BGsubscriptğµğºB_{G}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where the â€œerrorâ€ Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ takes the minimum possible value: Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0\epsilon_{0}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
We aim to prove Theorems 5 by showing that for any graph GğºGitalic_G there exists an Î´0subscriptğ›¿0\delta_{0}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that:

â€–FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰0â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))âˆ’FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)â€–â€–FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)â€–<Î´0normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ”0subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ›¿0\frac{\|F_{\theta}(P_{\omega_{0}}(G_{ori}))-F_{\theta}(G_{bri})\|}{\|F_{\theta% }(G_{bri})\|}<\delta_{0}divide start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ end_ARG < italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

According to lemma 7 and 8, for both GPF and All-in-One prompts, there exists a convex cone Cğ¶Citalic_C such that:

KÎ¸â¢(GÏ‰)=H(n)=ğœğ©âŠ¤subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğºğœ”superscriptğ»ğ‘›superscriptğœğ©topK_{\theta}(G_{\omega})=H^{(n)}=\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

where ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p is on the surface of such convex cone, i.e., âˆ‚Cğ¶\partial Câˆ‚ italic_C, and FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta}(G_{bri})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a vector inside the convex cone Cğ¶Citalic_C.

Using the same readout method as in A.3.2, we have:

FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))=âˆ‘iwiâ¢Hi(n)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢ğœğ©âŠ¤=Î»â¢ğ©âŠ¤subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptğ°topsuperscriptğœğ©topğœ†superscriptğ©topF_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))=\sum_{i}w_{i}H^{(n)}_{i}=\mathbf{w}^{\top}% \mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}=\lambda\mathbf{p}^{\top}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Î» bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

where ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p spans surface of the convex cone (âˆ‚Cğ¶\partial Câˆ‚ italic_C). Based on the properties of the cone surface, Î»â¢ğ©ğœ†ğ©\lambda\mathbf{p}italic_Î» bold_p is on the cone surface for any Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0, so we have FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–F_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) spans the cone surface âˆ‚Cğ¶\partial Câˆ‚ italic_C.

Consider â€–FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)âˆ’FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))â€–normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–\|F_{\theta}(G_{bri})-F_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))\|âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) âˆ¥. The minimum value of this distance, according to definition 3, is the distance from an element in the convex cone to the cone surface, which is sinâ¡(Î¸)â¢â€–vâ€–ğœƒnormğ‘£\sin(\theta)\|v\|roman_sin ( italic_Î¸ ) âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥, where Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ represents the angle of vğ‘£vitalic_v to the surface.

This proves that â€–FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))âˆ’FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢iâ¢dâ¢gâ¢e)â€–â€–FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢iâ¢dâ¢gâ¢e)â€–normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’\frac{\|F_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))-F_{\theta}(G_{bridge})\|}{\|F_{\theta}% (G_{bridge})\|}divide start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i italic_d italic_g italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i italic_d italic_g italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ end_ARG has a upper bound, sinâ¡(Î¸)ğœƒ\sin(\theta)roman_sin ( italic_Î¸ ), where Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ is related to both vğ‘£vitalic_v and Cğ¶Citalic_C.

According to definition 4, we know that Î¸â‰¤Î¦/2ğœƒÎ¦2\theta\leq\Phi/2italic_Î¸ â‰¤ roman_Î¦ / 2, where Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ represents the aperture of the cone Cğ¶Citalic_C.

In summary:

â€–FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))âˆ’Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)â€–normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle\|F_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))-C(G_{ori})\|âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ =â€–FÎ¸â¢(PÏ‰â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i))âˆ’FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)â€–absentnormsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ”subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle=\|F_{\theta}(P_{\omega}(G_{ori}))-F_{\theta}(G_{bri})\|= âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ (40)
â‰¤sinâ¡(Î¦/2)â‹…â€–FÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)â€–absentâ‹…Î¦2normsubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle\leq\sin(\Phi/2)\cdot\|F_{\theta}(G_{bri})\|â‰¤ roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ) â‹… âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ (41)
=sinâ¡(Î¦/2)â‹…â€–Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)â€–absentâ‹…Î¦2normğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle=\sin(\Phi/2)\cdot\|C(G_{ori})\|= roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ) â‹… âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ (42)

The left part of the error upper bound (sinâ¡(Î¦/2)Î¦2\sin(\Phi/2)roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 )) is only related to the model, while the right part is only related to the data (Goâ¢râ¢isubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–G_{ori}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). This indicates that the error upper bound grows linearly with â€–Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)â€–normğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–\|C(G_{ori})\|âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ by a coefficient, i.e. sinâ¡(Î¦/2)Î¦2\sin(\Phi/2)roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ).

Since the features magnitude and number of node of the graph data in the dataset have upper bounds, â€–Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)â€–normğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–\|C(G_{ori})\|âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ also has an upper bound Cğ¶Citalic_C.Hence, for the dataset, there is a uniform upper bound, which demonstrates that the model is effective and can utilize the powerful pre-trained model within a certain error range. âˆ

A.3.4 Error Bound Analysis of Mapping to Bridge Set at Multiple Graph Level

Proof of Theorems 6

Proof.

We prove this theorem by considering the sum of squared of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ, where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ denotes the degree of the bridge set extension. For simplicity, we will refer to it as the â€œerrorâ€.
Consider a dataset with M graphs. We use either a single prompt vector GPF or a single node-prompted subgraph All-in-one approach. According to lemma 4, for each graph, we have the following formula:

KÎ¸â¢(Gi,Ï‰)=Hi(n)=Ri(n)+ğœiâ¢ğ©âŠ¤subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘–ğœ”superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœğ‘–superscriptğ©topK_{\theta}(G_{i},\omega)=H_{i}^{(n)}=R_{i}^{(n)}+\mathbf{c}_{i}\mathbf{p}^{\top}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï‰ ) = italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (43)

where ğœisubscriptğœğ‘–\mathbf{c}_{i}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have the subscript iğ‘–iitalic_i to indicate that different graphs produce different ğœğœ\mathbf{c}bold_c, ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p spans â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p does not have a subscript iğ‘–iitalic_i because single Prompt Vector is used for all graphs, despite different graphs having different diffusion matrices Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and feature matrices Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X.

After performing the ReadOut operation, we get:

FÎ¸â¢(Gi)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢Hi(n)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢Ri(n)+ğ°âŠ¤â¢ğœiâ¢ğ©âŠ¤=R0âŠ¤+Î»iâ¢ğ©âŠ¤subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘–superscriptğ°topsuperscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptğ°topsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptğ°topsubscriptğœğ‘–superscriptğ©topsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘…0topsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–superscriptğ©topF_{\theta}(G_{i})=\mathbf{w}^{\top}H_{i}^{(n)}=\mathbf{w}^{\top}R_{i}^{(n)}+% \mathbf{w}^{\top}\mathbf{c}_{i}\mathbf{p}^{\top}=R_{0}^{\top}+\lambda_{i}% \mathbf{p}^{\top}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (44)

Where Î»i=ğ°âŠ¤â¢ğœisubscriptğœ†ğ‘–superscriptğ°topsubscriptğœğ‘–\lambda_{i}=\mathbf{w}^{\top}\mathbf{c}_{i}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can assume R0âŠ¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘…0topR_{0}^{\top}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a zero matrix without loss of generality as discussed in lemma 7.

Now, consider the sum of squared â€œerrorsâ€:

âˆ‘i=1Mâ€–Câ¢(Gi)âˆ’Î»iâ¢ğ©â€–2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptnormğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ©2\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}\|C(G_{i})-\lambda_{i}\mathbf{p}\|^{2}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =âˆ‘i=1MÎ»i2â¢â€–(1/Î»i)â¢Câ¢(Gi)âˆ’ğ©â€–2absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–2superscriptnorm1subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–ğ©2\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{M}\lambda_{i}^{2}\|(1/\lambda_{i})C(G_{i})-\mathbf{p% }\|^{2}= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ ( 1 / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_p âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (45)
=âˆ‘i=1MÎ»i2â¢â€–CÎ»iâ¢(Gi)âˆ’ğ©â€–2absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ¶subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğºğ‘–ğ©2\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{M}\lambda_{i}^{2}\|C_{\lambda_{i}}(G_{i})-\mathbf{p}% \|^{2}= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_p âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (46)

The optimal Ï‰0subscriptğœ”0\omega_{0}italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponds to correspond to minimizing the following loss value.

J=âˆ‘i=1MÎ»i2â¢â€–CÎ»iâ¢(Gi)âˆ’ğ©â€–2ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ¶subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğºğ‘–ğ©2J=\sum_{i=1}^{M}\lambda_{i}^{2}\|C_{\lambda_{i}}(G_{i})-\mathbf{p}\|^{2}italic_J = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_p âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (47)

Which is the weighted sum of squared distances from ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p to Mğ‘€Mitalic_M different points in the space, denoted as: Dâ¢((CÎ»1â¢(G1),â€¦,CÎ»nâ¢(Gn)),(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n))ğ·subscriptğ¶subscriptğœ†1subscriptğº1â€¦subscriptğ¶subscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğºğ‘›subscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›D((C_{\lambda_{1}}(G_{1}),\ldots,C_{\lambda_{n}}(G_{n})),(\lambda_{1},\ldots,% \lambda_{n}))italic_D ( ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )

The optimal pğ‘pitalic_p is the weighted centroid of these nğ‘›nitalic_n vectors (CÎ»iâ¢(Gi))i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ¶subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘€(C_{\lambda_{i}}(G_{i}))_{i=1}^{M}( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as pointed out at Boyd & Vandenberghe (2004), i.e.:

ğ©âˆ—=âˆ‘i=1MÎ»iâ¢Câ¢(Gi)âˆ‘i=1MÎ»i2superscriptğ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–2\mathbf{p}^{*}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\lambda_{i}C(G_{i})}{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\lambda_% {i}^{2}}bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG (48)

The closed-form expression for Jmâ¢iâ¢nsubscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›J_{min}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is:

Jmâ¢iâ¢n=âˆ‘i=1Mâ€–Câ¢(Gi)âˆ’Î»iâ¢ğ©âˆ—â€–2subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptnormğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–superscriptğ©2J_{min}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}\|C(G_{i})-\lambda_{i}\mathbf{p}^{*}\|^{2}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (49)

Therefore, the minimum root mean squared of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ value(â€œRMSEâ€) Iâ¢(G1,â€¦,Gn)ğ¼subscriptğº1â€¦subscriptğºğ‘›I(G_{1},\ldots,G_{n})italic_I ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) satisfies

Iâ¢(G1,â€¦,GM)ğ¼subscriptğº1â€¦subscriptğºğ‘€\displaystyle I(G_{1},\ldots,G_{M})italic_I ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =minÏ‰â¡(âˆ‘i=1MÎ»i2â¢â€–CÎ»iâ¢(Gi)âˆ’ğ©â€–2/M)=âˆ‘i=1Mâ€–Câ¢(Gi)âˆ’Î»iâ¢ğ©âˆ—â€–2/Mabsentsubscriptğœ”superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ¶subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğºğ‘–ğ©2ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptnormğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–superscriptğ©2ğ‘€\displaystyle=\min_{\omega}(\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\lambda_{i}^{2}\|C_{\lambda_{i% }}(G_{i})-\mathbf{p}\|^{2}/M})=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{M}\|C(G_{i})-\lambda_{i}% \mathbf{p}^{*}\|^{2}/M}= roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_p âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_M end_ARG ) = square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_M end_ARG (50)
=Jmâ¢iâ¢nMabsentsubscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘€\displaystyle=\sqrt{\frac{J_{min}}{M}}= square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_ARG (51)

Here, Iâ¢(G1,â€¦,GM)ğ¼subscriptğº1â€¦subscriptğºğ‘€I(G_{1},\ldots,G_{M})italic_I ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a lower bound that is independent of the value of Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰, but is related to the distances between Câ¢(Gi)ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–C(G_{i})italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). This proves that the capability of a single prompt has an upper limit in this case, which proves Theorem 6. âˆ

Proof of Theorem 7

Proof.

We validate this theorem by minimizing the sum of squared of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ, where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ denotes the degree of the bridge set extension. For simplicity, we will refer to it as the â€œerrorâ€.
Consider a dataset with M graphs. We use k prompt vectors for GPF or k node-prompted subgraphs. According to lemma 6, for each graph, we have:

Hi(n)=KÎ¸â¢(Gi,Ï‰)=Ri(n)+ğœiâ¢QiâŠ¤â¢Psuperscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘–ğœ”superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„topğ‘–ğ‘ƒH_{i}^{(n)}=K_{\theta}(G_{i},\omega)=R_{i}^{(n)}+\mathbf{c}_{i}Q^{\top}_{i}Pitalic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï‰ ) = italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P (52)

where Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P spans â„kÃ—Fsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{k\times F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k Ã— italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q represents the combination coefficients of different Prompts, and spans â„MÃ—ksuperscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘˜\mathbb{R}^{M\times k}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M Ã— italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As discussed in Proof for Theorem 6, we can assume Ri(n)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘›{R}_{i}^{(n)}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a zero matrix for simplicity.

After the ReadOut operation:

FÎ¸â¢(Gi)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢Hi(n)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢ğœiâ¢QiâŠ¤â¢P=Î»iâ¢QiâŠ¤â¢Psubscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘–superscriptğ°topsuperscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptğ°topsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„topğ‘–ğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„topğ‘–ğ‘ƒF_{\theta}(G_{i})=\mathbf{w}^{\top}H_{i}^{(n)}=\mathbf{w}^{\top}\mathbf{c}_{i}% Q^{\top}_{i}P=\lambda_{i}Q^{\top}_{i}Pitalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P = italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P (53)

Since Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT spans â„ksuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜\mathbb{R}^{k}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Î»iâ¢Qi=Qiâ€²subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘–\lambda_{i}Q_{i}=Q^{\prime}_{i}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also spans â„ksuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜\mathbb{R}^{k}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (Î»i>0subscriptğœ†ğ‘–0\lambda_{i}>0italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0). Thus, FÎ¸â¢(Gi)subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘–F_{\theta}(G_{i})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) spans the row space Râ¢(P)ğ‘…ğ‘ƒR(P)italic_R ( italic_P ), which is (at most) a kğ‘˜kitalic_k-dimensional vector space determined by kğ‘˜kitalic_k independent prompt vectors.
Consider:

âˆ‘i=1Mâ€–CâŠ¤â¢(Gi)âˆ’Qâ€²iâŠ¤â¢Pâ€–2=âˆ‘i=1Mâ€–Câ¢(Gi)âˆ’ğ©â€²iâ€–2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptnormsuperscriptğ¶topsubscriptğºğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²topğ‘–ğ‘ƒ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptnormğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ©â€²ğ‘–2\sum_{i=1}^{M}\|C^{\top}(G_{i})-{Q^{\prime}}^{\top}_{i}P\|^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}% \|C(G_{i})-\mathbf{p^{\prime}}_{i}\|^{2}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (54)

where ğ©â€²isubscriptsuperscriptğ©â€²ğ‘–\mathbf{p^{\prime}}_{i}bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT spans the row space of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Equation 54 is the sum of squared distances from n vectors to the vector space Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. We want to minimize:

J=âˆ‘i=1Mâ€–Câ¢(Gi)âˆ’ğ©â€²iâ€–2ğ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptnormğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ©â€²ğ‘–2J=\sum_{i=1}^{M}\|C(G_{i})-\mathbf{p^{\prime}}_{i}\|^{2}italic_J = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (55)

Let S=[C(G1),â€¦,C(GM]S=[C(G_{1}),\ldots,C(G_{M}]italic_S = [ italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] and V=SâŠ¤â¢Sğ‘‰superscriptğ‘†topğ‘†V=S^{\top}Sitalic_V = italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S. According to lemma 11, the minimum value of Jğ½Jitalic_J is the sum of the (k+1)ğ‘˜1(k+1)( italic_k + 1 )-th to Mğ‘€Mitalic_M-th largest eigenvalues of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V:

Jmâ¢iâ¢n=âˆ‘i=k+1MÎ»iVsubscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘€subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘‰ğ‘–J_{min}=\sum_{i=k+1}^{M}\lambda^{V}_{i}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (56)

Where Î»iVsubscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘‰ğ‘–\lambda^{V}_{i}italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the itâ¢hsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i_{th}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT largest eigenvalue of symmetric matrix Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. Therefore, there exists an optimal Ï‰0subscriptğœ”0\omega_{0}italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the mean squared epsilon(error) is:

â„’â¢(G1,â‹¯,GM)=âˆ‘i=k+1MÎ»iVMâ„’subscriptğº1â‹¯subscriptğºğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘€\mathcal{L}(G_{1},\cdots,G_{M})=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=k+1}^{M}\lambda_{i}^{V}}{M}}caligraphic_L ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_M end_ARG end_ARG (57)

This indicates that in the multiple prompt framework, the optimal mean squared Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ has an upper bound â„’â¢(G1,â‹¯,GM)â„’subscriptğº1â‹¯subscriptğºğ‘€\mathcal{L}(G_{1},\cdots,G_{M})caligraphic_L ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which proves Theorem 7.

Notably, if kâ‰¥nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\geq nitalic_k â‰¥ italic_n, we can find a suitable Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P such that FÎ¸â¢(Gi)subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘–F_{\theta}(G_{i})italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Câ¢(Gi)ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘–C(G_{i})italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are error-free for any iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,M}ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘€i\in\{1,\cdots,M\}italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â‹¯ , italic_M }. This can be seen as an extension of Theorems 3 and 4. âˆ

Remark 4.

As Johnstone (2001) pointed out, the eigenvalues of V=CâŠ¤â¢Cğ‘‰superscriptğ¶topğ¶V=C^{\top}Citalic_V = italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C in datasets often exhibit a truncated eigenvalue distribution. The first k0subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT eigenvalues explain most of the variance. Furthermore, Jolliffe & Cadima (2016) shows that in many datasets, eigenvalues may exhibit exponential decay. Hence, the sum of remaining eigenvalues decreases rapidly as kğ‘˜kitalic_k increases. This could explain why moderate-scale prompts are sufficient to achieve good results on large graph datasets.

A.3.5 Error Distribution Analysis of Mapping to Bridge Set

Proof of Theorem 8

Proof.

Consider a GNN model FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W matrix in the last layer is not full rank. Denote by Fâˆ’rğ¹ğ‘ŸF-ritalic_F - italic_r the rank of the Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W weight matrix in the last layer. Consider a GPF prompt or a single node prompt in an All-in-one framework.

According to lemma 4, we have:

H(nâˆ’1)=R(nâˆ’1)+ğœğ©âŠ¤superscriptğ»ğ‘›1superscriptğ‘…ğ‘›1superscriptğœğ©topH^{(n-1)}=R^{(n-1)}+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (58)

where H(nâˆ’1)superscriptğ»ğ‘›1H^{(n-1)}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the (nâˆ’1)tâ¢hsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘¡â„(n-1)_{th}( italic_n - 1 ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT order embedding matrix, ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p spans â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As discussed in lemma 7, for simplicity, we can assume R(nâˆ’1)=0superscriptğ‘…ğ‘›10R^{(n-1)}=0italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. Then:

KÎ¸â¢(GÏ‰)=Hnâ¢(GÏ‰)subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğºğœ”superscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğºğœ”\displaystyle K_{\theta}(G_{\omega})=H^{n}(G_{\omega})italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =Ïƒâ¢(SÏ‰â¢(R(nâˆ’1)+ğœğ©âŠ¤)â¢W)absentğœsubscriptğ‘†ğœ”superscriptğ‘…ğ‘›1superscriptğœğ©topğ‘Š\displaystyle=\sigma(S_{\omega}(R^{(n-1)}+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top})W)= italic_Ïƒ ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_W ) (59)
=Ïƒâ¢(SÏ‰â¢ğœğ©âŠ¤â¢W)absentğœsubscriptğ‘†ğœ”superscriptğœğ©topğ‘Š\displaystyle=\sigma(S_{\omega}\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}W)= italic_Ïƒ ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W )
=Ïƒâ¢(ğœâ€²â¢ğ©â€²âŠ¤)absentğœsuperscriptğœâ€²superscriptsuperscriptğ©â€²top\displaystyle=\sigma(\mathbf{c^{\prime}}\mathbf{p^{\prime}}^{\top})= italic_Ïƒ ( bold_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

where ğ©â€²superscriptğ©â€²\mathbf{p}^{\prime}bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT spans the row space Râ¢(W)ğ‘…ğ‘ŠR(W)italic_R ( italic_W ).

Consider KÎ¸â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)=H(n)â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)=(ğ¯1âŠ¤â‹®ğ¯nâŠ¤)subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–matrixsubscriptsuperscriptğ¯top1â‹®subscriptsuperscriptğ¯topğ‘›K_{\theta}(G_{bri})=H^{(n)}(G_{bri})=\begin{pmatrix}\mathbf{v}^{\top}_{1}\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{v}^{\top}_{n}\end{pmatrix}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ), where ğ¯iâˆˆâ„Fsubscriptğ¯ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbf{v}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{F}bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Then, Î”â¢FÎ¸â¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)=FÎ¸â¢(GÏ‰)âˆ’Câ¢(Goâ¢râ¢i)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢H(n)â¢(GÏ‰)âˆ’ğ°âŠ¤â¢H(n)â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i)=ğ°âŠ¤â¢(H(n)â¢(GÏ‰)âˆ’H(n)â¢(Gbâ¢râ¢i))=ğ°âŠ¤â¢Î”â¢HÎ”subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğœƒsubscriptğºğœ”ğ¶subscriptğºğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ°topsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğºğœ”superscriptğ°topsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ°topsuperscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğºğœ”superscriptğ»ğ‘›subscriptğºğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ°topÎ”ğ»\Delta F_{\theta}(G_{ori})=F_{\theta}(G_{\omega})-C(G_{ori})=\mathbf{w}^{\top}% H^{(n)}(G_{\omega})-\mathbf{w}^{\top}H^{(n)}(G_{bri})=\mathbf{w}^{\top}(H^{(n)% }(G_{\omega})-H^{(n)}(G_{bri}))=\mathbf{w}^{\top}\Delta Hroman_Î” italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_C ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b italic_r italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_H.

Here, Î”â¢Hiâ¢j=Ïƒâ¢(ciâ¢pjâ€²)âˆ’viâ¢j=Ïƒâ¢(ciâ¢pjâ€²âˆ’Ïƒâˆ’1â¢(viâ¢j))Î”subscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘—superscriptğœ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta H_{ij}=\sigma(c_{i}p^{\prime}_{j})-v_{ij}=\sigma(c_{i}p^{\prime}_{j}-% \sigma^{-1}(v_{ij}))roman_Î” italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ).

Then pâ€²â£âˆ—âˆˆRâ¢(W)superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘…ğ‘Šp^{\prime*}\in R(W)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_R ( italic_W ), so â€–Î”â¢FÎ¸â¢(G)â€–=â€–pâ€²â£âˆ—âˆ’ğœ·â€–normÎ”subscriptğ¹ğœƒğºnormsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğœ·\|\Delta F_{\theta}(G)\|=\|p^{\prime*}-\bm{\beta}\|âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î² âˆ¥. Since pâ€²â£âˆ—superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT already minimizes â€–ğ‘¨â¢pâ€²âˆ’ğœ·â€–normğ‘¨superscriptğ‘â€²ğœ·\|\bm{A}p^{\prime}-\bm{\beta}\|âˆ¥ bold_italic_A italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î² âˆ¥ and ğ‘¨â¢pâ€²âˆˆRâ¢(ğ‘¨â¢W)ğ‘¨superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘…ğ‘¨ğ‘Š\bm{A}p^{\prime}\in R(\bm{A}W)bold_italic_A italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_R ( bold_italic_A italic_W ), âˆ€pâ€²âˆˆRâ¢(W)for-allsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘…ğ‘Š\forall p^{\prime}\in R(W)âˆ€ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_R ( italic_W ), where ğ‘¨ğ‘¨\bm{A}bold_italic_A denotes dâ¢iâ¢aâ¢gâ¢(Î±1,â‹¯,Î±F)ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘”subscriptğ›¼1â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ¹diag(\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{F})italic_d italic_i italic_a italic_g ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),we can estimate â€–pâˆ—â€²âˆ’ğœ·â€–normsuperscriptğ‘superscriptâ€²ğœ·\|p^{*^{\prime}}-\bm{\beta}\|âˆ¥ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î² âˆ¥ using the distance from ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² to the space Râ¢(ğ‘¨â¢W)ğ‘…ğ‘¨ğ‘ŠR(\bm{A}W)italic_R ( bold_italic_A italic_W ).

Consider the projection matrix Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P onto the space Râ¢(ğ‘¨â¢W)ğ‘…ğ‘¨ğ‘ŠR(\bm{A}W)italic_R ( bold_italic_A italic_W ). Then â€–Î”â¢FÎ¸â¢(G)â€–=â€–(Iâˆ’P)â¢ğœ·â€–normÎ”subscriptğ¹ğœƒğºnormğ¼ğ‘ƒğœ·\|\Delta F_{\theta}(G)\|=\|(I-P)\bm{\beta}\|âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ ( italic_I - italic_P ) bold_italic_Î² âˆ¥.

We make the following assumption: when pj=pjâˆ—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}=p^{*}_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Î²jsubscriptğ›½ğ‘—\beta_{j}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows an i.i.d. normal distribution.

Î²j=âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ’(Î±)kâ¢wiâ¢viâ¢j,whereÂ â¢k={0ifÂ â¢Ïƒâ¢(ciâ¢pjâ€²âˆ’Ïƒâˆ’1â¢(viâ¢j))>0âˆ’1otherwiseformulae-sequencesubscriptğ›½ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—whereÂ ğ‘˜cases0ifÂ ğœsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘—superscriptğœ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—01otherwise\beta_{j}=\sum^{N}_{i=1}-(\alpha)^{k}w_{i}v_{ij},\quad\text{where }k=\begin{% cases}0&\text{if }\sigma(c_{i}p^{\prime}_{j}-\sigma^{-1}(v_{ij}))>0\\ -1&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( italic_Î± ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , where italic_k = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_Ïƒ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) > 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW (60)

Where Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is the is the parameter of the Leaky-ReLU. According to the Central Limit Theorem and the independence of different components in ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î², it is reasonable to assume that ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² follows an nğ‘›nitalic_n-dimensional i.i.d. normal distribution with mean 0 and variance cğ‘citalic_c for some positive constant cğ‘citalic_c as discussed in 5.

Since Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is an (Fâˆ’r)ğ¹ğ‘Ÿ(F-r)( italic_F - italic_r )-dimensional projection matrix, according to lemma 13,we know that â€–(Iâˆ’P)â¢ğœ·â€–normğ¼ğ‘ƒğœ·\|(I-P)\bm{\beta}\|âˆ¥ ( italic_I - italic_P ) bold_italic_Î² âˆ¥ follows a Chi distribution with rğ‘Ÿritalic_r degrees of freedom and scalar cğ‘citalic_c, i.e. cÏ‡rsubscriptğœ’ğ‘Ÿ\chi_{r}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. âˆ

Remark 5.

Here, our equationÂ 58 implicitly assumes that the first Nâˆ’1ğ‘1N-1italic_N - 1 layers of GNN are of full rank. However, even if the rank of the first Nâˆ’1ğ‘1N-1italic_N - 1 layers of GNN could be non-full-rank, we still have ğ©â€²âˆˆRâ¢(W)superscriptğ©â€²ğ‘…ğ‘Š\mathbf{p^{\prime}}\in R(W)bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_R ( italic_W ), according to lemma 3. Therefore, we can still use this theorem for approximation.

Normal Distribution Assumption

We assume that the vector ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î², which we call the graph embedding residual vector, follows an Fğ¹Fitalic_F-dimensional i.i.d. normal distribution with mean ğŸ0\mathbf{0}bold_0 and variance cğ‘citalic_c:

ğœ·âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,câ¢IF)similar-toğœ·ğ’©0ğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ¹\bm{\beta}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,cI_{F})bold_italic_Î² âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_c italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (61)

where IFsubscriptğ¼ğ¹I_{F}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the FÃ—Fğ¹ğ¹F\times Fitalic_F Ã— italic_F identity matrix.

Intuitively, this graph embedding residual vector ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² represents the additional term that the graph needs to fit due to non-full-rank and non-linear components. Formally, its components are defined as:

[ğœ·]j=âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ’(Î±)kâ¢wiâ¢viâ¢j,whereÂ â¢k={0ifÂ â¢Ïƒâ¢(ciâ¢pjâ€²âˆ’Ïƒâˆ’1â¢(viâ¢j))>0âˆ’1otherwiseformulae-sequencesubscriptdelimited-[]ğœ·ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—whereÂ ğ‘˜cases0ifÂ ğœsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘—superscriptğœ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘—01otherwise[\bm{\beta}]_{j}=\sum^{N}_{i=1}-(\alpha)^{k}w_{i}v_{ij},\quad\text{where }k=% \begin{cases}0&\text{if }\sigma(c_{i}p^{\prime}_{j}-\sigma^{-1}(v_{ij}))>0\\ -1&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}[ bold_italic_Î² ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( italic_Î± ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , where italic_k = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_Ïƒ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) > 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW (62)

The reasons behind this assumption are as follows: (1). Symmetry (2). The sum of random variables and Central Limit Theorem: Each Î²jsubscriptğ›½ğ‘—\beta_{j}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a sum of multiple terms, each of which can be considered a random variable. The Central Limit Theorem suggests that its distribution should approach a normal distribution. (3). Continuous and smooth distribution (4). Independence: The components of ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² are assumed to be independent due to the independence of the input features and the structure of the GNN.

Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² follows an Fğ¹Fitalic_F-dimensional i.i.d. normal distribution with mean 0 and variance cğ‘citalic_c for some positive constant cğ‘citalic_c.

A.3.6 Analysis of Nonlinear Graph Neural Networks

Proof of Theorem 9

Proof.

According to Preliminary 1, we choose the simplest form of GAT here, with only a self-attention mechanism. We consider the diffusion matrix Sğ‘†Sitalic_S as a weighted adjacency matrix, where each entry Siâ¢jsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{ij}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the coefficient of the edge between node iğ‘–iitalic_i and node jğ‘—jitalic_j. Such coefficient is a non-negative scalar, which can be understood as the weight of the edge connecting node iğ‘–iitalic_i and node jğ‘—jitalic_j, Sâˆˆ[0,1]NÃ—Nğ‘†superscript01ğ‘ğ‘S\in[0,1]^{N\times N}italic_S âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N Ã— italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Here, single-node All-in-one connection matrices Aiâ¢nâˆˆ[0,1]1Ã—1subscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘›superscript0111A_{in}\in[0,1]^{1\times 1}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 Ã— 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Acâ¢râ¢oâˆˆ[0,1]NÃ—1subscriptğ´ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œsuperscript01ğ‘1A_{cro}\in[0,1]^{N\times 1}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_r italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N Ã— 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. Then, we have such an iterative formula:

H(m)=Ïƒâ¢((SÏ‰âŠ™âŸ¨XÏ‰,XÏ‰âŸ©)â‹…XÏ‰â‹…W)superscriptğ»ğ‘šğœâ‹…direct-productsubscriptğ‘†ğœ”subscriptğ‘‹ğœ”subscriptğ‘‹ğœ”subscriptğ‘‹ğœ”ğ‘ŠH^{(m)}=\sigma((S_{\omega}\odot\langle X_{\omega},X_{\omega}\rangle)\cdot X_{% \omega}\cdot W)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ™ âŸ¨ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© ) â‹… italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_W )

where âŠ™direct-product\odotâŠ™ denotes the Hadamard product, representing element-wise multiplication of two matrices, âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©â‹…â‹…\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangleâŸ¨ â‹… , â‹… âŸ© represents the inner product of 2 matrices. In this case, we have:

XÏ‰=(Xğ©âŠ¤)subscriptğ‘‹ğœ”matrixğ‘‹superscriptğ©topX_{\omega}=\begin{pmatrix}X\\ \mathbf{p}^{\top}\end{pmatrix}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_X end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG )

SÏ‰=(SllâŠ¤0)subscriptğ‘†ğœ”matrixğ‘†ğ‘™superscriptğ‘™top0S_{\omega}=\begin{pmatrix}S&l\\ l^{\top}&0\end{pmatrix}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_S end_CELL start_CELL italic_l end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG )

Where lğ‘™litalic_l denotes the cross adjacency matrix Acâ¢râ¢oâˆˆ[0,1]Nsubscriptğ´ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œsuperscript01ğ‘A_{cro}\in[0,1]^{N}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_r italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we have:

SÏ‰âŠ™âŸ¨XÏ‰,XÏ‰âŸ©â¢Wdirect-productsubscriptğ‘†ğœ”subscriptğ‘‹ğœ”subscriptğ‘‹ğœ”ğ‘Š\displaystyle S_{\omega}\odot\langle X_{\omega},X_{\omega}\rangle Witalic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ™ âŸ¨ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© italic_W =(SâŠ™âŸ¨X,XâŸ©lâŠ™(Xâ‹…ğ©)lTâŠ™(Xâ‹…ğ©)T0)â‹…(Xğ©âŠ¤)â‹…Wabsentâ‹…matrixdirect-productğ‘†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹direct-productğ‘™â‹…ğ‘‹ğ©direct-productsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘‡superscriptâ‹…ğ‘‹ğ©ğ‘‡0matrixğ‘‹superscriptğ©topğ‘Š\displaystyle=\begin{pmatrix}S\odot\langle X,X\rangle&l\odot(X\cdot\mathbf{p})% \\ l^{T}\odot(X\cdot\mathbf{p})^{T}&0\end{pmatrix}\cdot\begin{pmatrix}X\\ \mathbf{p}^{\top}\end{pmatrix}\cdot W= ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_S âŠ™ âŸ¨ italic_X , italic_X âŸ© end_CELL start_CELL italic_l âŠ™ ( italic_X â‹… bold_p ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ™ ( italic_X â‹… bold_p ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_X end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… italic_W (63)

For simplification, we consider only updating the embedding of rows of original nodes in the embedding matrix. Then we can obtain:

H[1:N,]\displaystyle H[1:N,]italic_H [ 1 : italic_N , ] =[(SâŠ™âŸ¨X,XâŸ©Xâ‹…(lâŠ™ğ©)lTâŠ™(Xâ‹…ğ©)T(ğ©âŠ¤â¢ğ©))â‹…(Xğ©âŠ¤)â‹…W][1:N,]\displaystyle=[\begin{pmatrix}S\odot\langle X,X\rangle&X\cdot(l\odot\mathbf{p}% )\\ l^{T}\odot(X\cdot\mathbf{p})^{T}&(\mathbf{p}^{\top}\mathbf{p})\end{pmatrix}% \cdot\begin{pmatrix}X\\ \mathbf{p}^{\top}\end{pmatrix}\cdot W][1:N,]= [ ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_S âŠ™ âŸ¨ italic_X , italic_X âŸ© end_CELL start_CELL italic_X â‹… ( italic_l âŠ™ bold_p ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ™ ( italic_X â‹… bold_p ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL ( bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_p ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_X end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… italic_W ] [ 1 : italic_N , ] (65)
=Ïƒâ¢((SâŠ™âŸ¨X,XâŸ©Xâ¢(lâŠ™ğ©))â‹…(Xğ©âŠ¤)â‹…W)absentğœâ‹…matrixdirect-productğ‘†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘‹direct-productğ‘™ğ©matrixğ‘‹superscriptğ©topğ‘Š\displaystyle=\sigma(\begin{pmatrix}S\odot\langle X,X\rangle&X(l\odot\mathbf{p% })\end{pmatrix}\cdot\begin{pmatrix}X\\ \mathbf{p}^{\top}\end{pmatrix}\cdot W)= italic_Ïƒ ( ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_S âŠ™ âŸ¨ italic_X , italic_X âŸ© end_CELL start_CELL italic_X ( italic_l âŠ™ bold_p ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_X end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… italic_W ) (66)
