Then, we have:

H[1:N,]\displaystyle H[1:N,]italic_H [ 1 : italic_N , ] =Ïƒâ¢((SâŠ™âŸ¨X,XâŸ©ğœ)â‹…(Xğ©âŠ¤)â‹…W)absentğœâ‹…matrixdirect-productğ‘†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğœmatrixğ‘‹superscriptğ©topğ‘Š\displaystyle=\sigma(\begin{pmatrix}S\odot\langle X,X\rangle&\mathbf{c}\end{% pmatrix}\cdot\begin{pmatrix}X\\ \mathbf{p}^{\top}\end{pmatrix}\cdot W)= italic_Ïƒ ( ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_S âŠ™ âŸ¨ italic_X , italic_X âŸ© end_CELL start_CELL bold_c end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_X end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… italic_W ) (68)
=Ïƒâ¢(Sâ€²â¢Xâ¢W+ğœâ€²â¢ğ©âŠ¤â¢W)absentğœsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘‹ğ‘Šsuperscriptğœâ€²superscriptğ©topğ‘Š\displaystyle=\sigma(S^{\prime}XW+\mathbf{c}^{\prime}\mathbf{p}^{\top}W)= italic_Ïƒ ( italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X italic_W + bold_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W ) (69)
=R+ğœğ©âŠ¤absentğ‘…superscriptğœğ©top\displaystyle=R+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}= italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (70)
H[N+1,]\displaystyle H[N+1,]italic_H [ italic_N + 1 , ] =ğ©âŠ¤absentsuperscriptğ©top\displaystyle=\mathbf{p}^{\top}= bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (71)
Hğ»\displaystyle Hitalic_H =Râ€²+ğœğ©âŠ¤absentsuperscriptğ‘…â€²superscriptğœğ©top\displaystyle=R^{\prime}+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}= italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (72)

where ğœğœ\mathbf{c}bold_c is chosen independent of ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p, ğœâ€²=(ğœ1)superscriptğœâ€²matrixğœ1\mathbf{c^{\prime}}=\begin{pmatrix}\mathbf{c}\\ 1\end{pmatrix}bold_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_c end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ). This translates to the iterative formula we have discussed earlier in 2. By analogy with the proofs of Theorems 3, 4, and 5, we can obtain similar Theorem 9. âˆ

A.4 Further Mathematical Discussion

Discussion on ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p:

In lemma 2, we rely on the claim that assumes Î”â¢R=ğœğ©0âŠ¤Î”ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptğœğ©0top\Delta R=\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}_{0}^{\top}roman_Î” italic_R = bold_cp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT wonâ€™t lose the generality. This assumption is mainly for simplification, allowing us to obtain Ïƒâ¢(Î”â¢R+ğœğ©âŠ¤)=ğœğ©â€²â£âŠ¤ğœÎ”ğ‘…superscriptğœğ©topsuperscriptğœğ©â€²top\sigma(\Delta R+\mathbf{cp}^{\top})=\mathbf{cp}^{\prime\top}italic_Ïƒ ( roman_Î” italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ©,ğ©â€²ğ©superscriptğ©â€²\mathbf{p},\mathbf{p^{\prime}}bold_p , bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT spans RFsuperscriptğ‘…ğ¹R^{F}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The core purpose of this assumption is that when Î”â¢R=ğœğ©âŠ¤Î”ğ‘…superscriptğœğ©top\Delta R=\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}roman_Î” italic_R = bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the Ï„iâ¢jsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—\tau_{ij}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT below is invariant to iğ‘–iitalic_i.

[Ïƒâ¢(R+câ¢pâŠ¤)]iâ¢j={[R+ğœğ©âŠ¤]iâ¢jwhenÂ â¢pjâ‰¥Ï„iâ¢jÎ±â¢[R+ğœğ©âŠ¤]iâ¢jwhenÂ â¢pj<Ï„iâ¢jsubscriptdelimited-[]ğœğ‘…ğ‘superscriptğ‘topğ‘–ğ‘—casessubscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘…superscriptğœğ©topğ‘–ğ‘—whenÂ subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ›¼subscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘…superscriptğœğ©topğ‘–ğ‘—whenÂ subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—[\sigma(R+cp^{\top})]_{ij}=\begin{cases}[R+\mathbf{cp}^{\top}]_{ij}&\text{when% }p_{j}\geq\tau_{ij}\\ \alpha[R+\mathbf{cp}^{\top}]_{ij}&\text{when }p_{j}<\tau_{ij}\end{cases}[ italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + italic_c italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL [ italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL when italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î± [ italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL when italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW

Use Ï„iâ¢jsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—\tau_{ij}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of iğ‘–iitalic_i, we can immediately establish a one-to-one mapping between ğ©â€²superscriptğ©â€²\mathbf{p^{\prime}}bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p, (i.e., pjâ€²={pjâˆ’Ï„jwhenÂ â¢pjâ‰¥Ï„j(pjâˆ’Ï„j)/Î±whenÂ â¢pj<Ï„jsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘—casessubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—whenÂ subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—ğ›¼whenÂ subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—p^{\prime}_{j}=\begin{cases}p_{j}-\tau_{j}&\text{when }p_{j}\geq\tau_{j}\\ (p_{j}-\tau_{j})/\alpha&\text{when }p_{j}<\tau_{j}\end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL when italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Î± end_CELL start_CELL when italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ), thereby successfully establishing an equivalence between changes in ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p at the input end and the ğ©â€²superscriptğ©â€²\mathbf{p}^{\prime}bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at the output end. This is what lemma 2 is doing. Noted that Î”â¢R=ğœğ©ğŸâŠ¤Î”ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptğœğ©0top\Delta R=\mathbf{cp_{0}^{\top}}roman_Î” italic_R = bold_cp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT donâ€™t hold in general.

Now let us prove that the specific form of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R does not affect the results based on ReadOut. This is equivalent to proving the following lemma:

Lemma 9 (Equivalence of R under ReadOut).

Considering a vector ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p spans RFsuperscriptğ‘…ğ¹R^{F}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then (1) ReadOut(Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©âŠ¤)ğœğ‘…superscriptğœğ©top\sigma(R+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )) spans RFsuperscriptğ‘…ğ¹R^{F}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. (2) Given ğ©isubscriptğ©ğ‘–\mathbf{p}_{i}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of each other, then [ReadOutâ¢(Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©âŠ¤))]isubscriptdelimited-[]ReadOutğœğ‘…superscriptğœğ©topğ‘–[\text{ReadOut}(\sigma(R+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}))]_{i}[ ReadOut ( italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of each other.

Consider the ReadOut of the Output Matrix Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©ğŸâŠ¤)ğœğ‘…superscriptsubscriptğœğ©0top\sigma(R+\mathbf{cp_{0}^{\top}})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), i.e. ReadOut(Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©âŠ¤)ğœğ‘…superscriptğœğ©top\sigma(R+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )). Then the jtâ¢hsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡â„j_{th}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT compoenet of such a â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vector is:

âˆ‘i=1Nwiâ¢[Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©âŠ¤)]iâ¢j=âˆ‘i=1N[wiâ¢(Riâ¢jâ¢(pj)+ciâ¢jâ¢(pj)â¢pj)]subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptdelimited-[]ğœğ‘…superscriptğœğ©topğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\sum^{N}_{i=1}w_{i}[\sigma(R+\mathbf{cp}^{\top})]_{ij}=\sum^{N}_{i=1}[w_{i}(R_% {ij}(p_{j})+c_{ij}(p_{j})p_{j})]âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]

where Riâ¢jâ¢(p)={Riâ¢jwhenÂ â¢pâ‰¥âˆ’Riâ¢j/ciÎ±â¢Riâ¢jotherwiseÂ subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘casessubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘—whenÂ ğ‘subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ›¼subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘—otherwiseÂ R_{ij}(p)=\begin{cases}R_{ij}&\text{when }p\geq-R_{ij}/c_{i}\\ \alpha R_{ij}&\text{otherwise }\end{cases}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL when italic_p â‰¥ - italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î± italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW, ciâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT likewise.

Here, subscript iğ‘–iitalic_i indicates summing by row. Then, considering each column jğ‘—jitalic_j, we have Fğ¹Fitalic_F independent functions of pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

pjâ€²â¢(pj)=âˆ‘i=1Nwiâ¢(Riâ¢jâ¢(pj)+ciâ¢jâ¢(pj)â¢pj)=Rjâ€²â¢(pj)+Cjâ€²â¢(pj)â¢pjsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—â€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}^{\prime}(p_{j})=\sum^{N}_{i=1}w_{i}(R_{ij}(p_{j})+c_{ij}(p_{j})p_{j})=R^% {\prime}_{j}(p_{j})+C^{\prime}_{j}(p_{j})p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Where pjâ€²â¢(â‹…)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘—â‹…p^{\prime}_{j}(\cdot)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) is a piece-wise linear function of pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ciâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ‘–C^{\prime}_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Riâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…â€²ğ‘–R^{\prime}_{i}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are corresponding piecewise linear coefficients of pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. such a piecewise linear function takes values in (âˆ’âˆ,+âˆ)(-\infty,+\infty)( - âˆ , + âˆ ). Considering the independence of Fğ¹Fitalic_F columns, it follows that (1) ReadOut(Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©âŠ¤)ğœğ‘…superscriptğœğ©top\sigma(R+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )) spans â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (2) each component of [ReadOutâ¢(Ïƒâ¢(R+ğœğ©âŠ¤))]delimited-[]ReadOutğœğ‘…superscriptğœğ©top[\text{ReadOut}(\sigma(R+\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p}^{\top}))][ ReadOut ( italic_Ïƒ ( italic_R + bold_cp start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ] is independent of each other. Which is what we need for the proofs of Theorems 3 and 4.

Discussion on Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q and Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P:

As lemma 7 pointed out, we may use the same notations Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q and Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P in the preceding and following layers, but they have different meanings. We write it to simplify the expressions. To verify it is valid under ReadOut perspective, as A.4 pointed out, the following lemma is required:

Lemma 10.

(Equivalence of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q under ReadOut) Consider a matrix Pâˆˆâ„kÃ—Fğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ¹P\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times F}italic_P âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k Ã— italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a matrix Qâˆˆâ„MÃ—kğ‘„superscriptâ„ğ‘€ğ‘˜Q\in\mathbb{R}^{M\times k}italic_Q âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M Ã— italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ©ğ¢âŠ¤=QiâŠ¤â¢Psubscriptsuperscriptğ©topğ¢superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–topğ‘ƒ\mathbf{p^{\top}_{i}}=Q_{i}^{\top}Pbold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P then ReadOut(Ïƒâ¢(ğœğ©ğ¢âŠ¤))ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ©ğ¢top(\sigma(\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p_{i}^{\top}}))( italic_Ïƒ ( bold_cp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) spans â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

According to lemma 9, we have:

[Câ¢(ğ©ğ¢)]j=[ReadOutâ¢(Ïƒâ¢(ğœğ©ğ¢âŠ¤))]j=âˆ‘i=1Nwiâ¢ciâ¢Ïƒâ¢([ğ©ğ¢]j)=Î»â¢Ïƒâ¢([ğ©ğ¢]j)subscriptdelimited-[]ğ¶subscriptğ©ğ¢ğ‘—subscriptdelimited-[]ReadOutğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ©ğ¢topğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğœsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğ¢ğ‘—ğœ†ğœsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğ¢ğ‘—[C(\mathbf{p_{i}})]_{j}=[\text{ReadOut}(\sigma(\mathbf{cp_{i}}^{\top}))]_{j}=% \sum^{N}_{i=1}w_{i}c_{i}\sigma([\mathbf{p_{i}}]_{j})=\lambda\sigma([\mathbf{p_% {i}}]_{j})[ italic_C ( bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ ReadOut ( italic_Ïƒ ( bold_cp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Î» italic_Ïƒ ( [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

Where ğ©ğ¢=Qiâ¢Psubscriptğ©ğ¢subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘ƒ\mathbf{p_{i}}=Q_{i}Pbold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P, wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the coefficient of ReadOut process, Câ¢(ğ©ğ¢)ğ¶subscriptğ©ğ¢C(\mathbf{p_{i}})italic_C ( bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denotes the embedding vector after ReadOut, Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» denotes âˆ‘i=1Nwiâ¢cisubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\sum^{N}_{i=1}w_{i}c_{i}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Hence, every component (with subscript jğ‘—jitalic_j) of the embedding vector Câ¢(â‹…)ğ¶â‹…C(\cdot)italic_C ( â‹… ) is a piece-wise linear function of [ğ©ğ¢]jsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğ¢ğ‘—[\mathbf{p_{i}}]_{j}[ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Specifically, this function is:

pâ€²â¢(pj)={Î»â¢pjifÂ â¢pjâ‰¥0Î±â¢Î»â¢pjotherwisesuperscriptğ‘â€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘—casesğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ifÂ subscriptğ‘ğ‘—0ğ›¼ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘—otherwisep^{\prime}(p_{j})=\begin{cases}\lambda p_{j}&\text{if }p_{j}\geq 0\\ \alpha\lambda p_{j}&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î» italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL if italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î± italic_Î» italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW

where Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is the coefficient of the leaky ReLU. range of such a function is (âˆ’âˆ,+âˆ)(-\infty,+\infty)( - âˆ , + âˆ ). Since Fğ¹Fitalic_F components of Câ¢(ğ©ğ¢)ğ¶subscriptğ©ğ¢C(\mathbf{p_{i}})italic_C ( bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is independent, ReadOut(Ïƒâ¢(ğœğ©ğ¢âŠ¤))ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ©ğ¢top(\sigma(\mathbf{c}\mathbf{p_{i}^{\top}}))( italic_Ïƒ ( bold_cp start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = Câ¢(ğ©ğ¢)ğ¶subscriptğ©ğ¢C(\mathbf{p_{i}})italic_C ( bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) spans â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Specific form of the bijective mapping of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q

Then, for each iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,M}ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘€i\in\{1,\cdots,M\}italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â‹¯ , italic_M }, we have a Embedding Vector Câ¢(ğ©i)ğ¶subscriptğ©ğ‘–C(\mathbf{p}_{i})italic_C ( bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Considering putting such Embedding Vectors into a matrix, i.e., C~~ğ¶\tilde{C}over~ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG = (Câ¢(p1)â‹®Câ¢(pM))matrixğ¶subscriptğ‘1â‹®ğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ‘€\begin{pmatrix}C(p_{1})\\ \vdots\\ C(p_{M})\end{pmatrix}( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_C ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_C ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ). Then:

C~~ğ¶\displaystyle\tilde{C}over~ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG =diagâ¢(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n)â¢(Ïƒâ¢(ğ©ğŸâŠ¤)â‹®Ïƒâ¢(ğ©ğŒâŠ¤))absentdiagsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›matrixğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ©top1â‹®ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ©topğŒ\displaystyle=\text{diag}(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n})\begin{pmatrix}\sigma% (\mathbf{p^{\top}_{1}})\\ \vdots\\ \sigma(\mathbf{p^{\top}_{M}})\end{pmatrix}= diag ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ïƒ ( bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ïƒ ( bold_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) (74)
=diagâ¢(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n)â¢(Î±I11â¢[ğ©ğŸ]1â¢â‹¯â¢Î±I1â¢Fâ¢[ğ©ğŸ]Fâ‹®Î±IMâ¢1â¢[ğ©ğŒ]1â¢â‹¯â¢Î±IMâ¢Fâ¢[ğ©ğŒ]F)absentdiagsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›matrixsuperscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼11subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©11â‹¯superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼1ğ¹subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©1ğ¹â‹®superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ‘€1subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğŒ1â‹¯superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ‘€ğ¹subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğŒğ¹\displaystyle=\text{diag}(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n})\begin{pmatrix}\alpha% ^{I_{11}}[\mathbf{p_{1}}]_{1}\cdots\alpha^{I_{1F}}[\mathbf{p_{1}}]_{F}\\ \vdots\\ \alpha^{I_{M1}}[\mathbf{p_{M}}]_{1}\cdots\alpha^{I_{MF}}[\mathbf{p_{M}}]_{F}\\ \end{pmatrix}= diag ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) (75)

Here, we claim that we can take Iiâ¢j=Ijsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¼ğ‘—I_{ij}=I_{j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by 6, i.e. for any iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,M}ğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘€i\in\{1,\cdots,M\}italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â‹¯ , italic_M }, Iiâ¢j=Ijsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¼ğ‘—I_{ij}=I_{j}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Then we have:

C~~ğ¶\displaystyle\tilde{C}over~ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG =diagâ¢(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n)â¢([ğ©ğŸ]1â¢â‹¯â¢[ğ©ğŸ]Fâ‹®[ğ©ğŒ]1â¢â‹¯â¢[ğ©ğŒ]F)â¢diagâ¢(Î±I1,â‹¯,Î±IF)absentdiagsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›matrixsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©11â‹¯subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©1ğ¹â‹®subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğŒ1â‹¯subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ©ğŒğ¹diagsuperscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼1â‹¯superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ¹\displaystyle=\text{diag}(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n})\begin{pmatrix}[% \mathbf{p_{1}}]_{1}\cdots[\mathbf{p_{1}}]_{F}\\ \vdots\\ [\mathbf{p_{M}}]_{1}\cdots[\mathbf{p_{M}}]_{F}\\ \end{pmatrix}\text{diag}(\alpha^{I_{1}},\cdots,\alpha^{I_{F}})= diag ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) diag ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (77)
=diagâ¢(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n)â‹…(ğ©ğŸâŠ¤â‹®ğ©ğŒâŠ¤)â‹…diagâ¢(Î±I1,â‹¯,Î±IF)absentâ‹…diagsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›matrixsuperscriptsubscriptğ©1topâ‹®superscriptsubscriptğ©ğŒtopdiagsuperscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼1â‹¯superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ¹\displaystyle=\text{diag}(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n})\cdot\begin{pmatrix}% \mathbf{p_{1}}^{\top}\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{p_{M}}^{\top}\end{pmatrix}\cdot\text{diag}(\alpha^{I_{1}},\cdots,% \alpha^{I_{F}})= diag ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‹… ( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ) â‹… diag ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (78)
=diagâ¢(Î»1,â€¦,Î»n)â‹…Qâ¢Pâ‹…diagâ¢(Î±I1,â‹¯,Î±IF)absentâ‹…â‹…diagsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘„ğ‘ƒdiagsuperscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼1â‹¯superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ¼ğ¹\displaystyle=\text{diag}(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{n})\cdot QP\cdot\text{% diag}(\alpha^{I_{1}},\cdots,\alpha^{I_{F}})= diag ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‹… italic_Q italic_P â‹… diag ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (79)
=Qâ€²â¢Pâ€²absentsuperscriptğ‘„â€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²\displaystyle=Q^{\prime}P^{\prime}= italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (80)

Where Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT give out the specific form of the bijective mapping between Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q in lemma 5.

Remark 6.

We demonstrate that the claim in Explanation A.4 does not affect the results in Theorems 6 and 7.

Theorem 6 is about the case of a single prompt, making the claim trivially true.

For Theorem 7, we are seeking an upper bound for the optimal case. Among all prompt parameters satisfying the claim, if we can obtain the result in 7. Then, based on the principle that the global minimum is less than or equal to any partial minimum, the error in the optimal prompt would only be smaller, making such upper bound smaller.

In conclusion, our assumption is valid.

Lemma 11 (Minimum Sum of Squared Distances from M Vectors to a k-dimensional Subspace).

Suppose we have M vectors in â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a k-dimensional subspace of â„Fsuperscriptâ„ğ¹\mathbb{R}^{F}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We consider the minimum sum of squared distances from these M vectors to the k-dimensional subspace. This is equivalent to minimizing the following objective:

J=â€–Xâˆ’Xâ¢Wâ¢WTâ€–F2=Trâ¢((Xâˆ’Xâ¢Wâ¢WT)Tâ¢(Xâˆ’Xâ¢Wâ¢WT))ğ½subscriptsuperscriptnormğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡2ğ¹Trsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡J=\|X-XWW^{T}\|^{2}_{F}=\text{Tr}((X-XWW^{T})^{T}(X-XWW^{T}))italic_J = âˆ¥ italic_X - italic_X italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Tr ( ( italic_X - italic_X italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X - italic_X italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )

Where Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a kÃ—Fğ‘˜ğ¹k\times Fitalic_k Ã— italic_F matrix. According to Hotelling (1933), let: XTâ¢X=Vâ¢Î›â¢VTsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡ğ‘‹ğ‘‰Î›superscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‡X^{T}X=V\Lambda V^{T}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X = italic_V roman_Î› italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is the matrix of eigenvectors and Î›Î›\Lambdaroman_Î› is the diagonal matrix of eigenvalues. The optimal Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is then the first kğ‘˜kitalic_k columns of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V: W=V[:,:k]W=V[:,:k]italic_W = italic_V [ : , : italic_k ]. Substituting this into the objective function:

Jğ½\displaystyle Jitalic_J =Tr(VÎ›VTâˆ’VÎ›VTVV[:,:k]V[:,:k]T\displaystyle=\text{Tr}(V\Lambda V^{T}-V\Lambda V^{T}VV[:,:k]V[:,:k]^{T}= Tr ( italic_V roman_Î› italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V roman_Î› italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
âˆ’VV[:,:k]V[:,:k]TÎ›VT+VV[:,:k]V[:,:k]TÎ›VTV[:,:k]V[:,:k]T)\displaystyle\quad-VV[:,:k]V[:,:k]^{T}\Lambda V^{T}+VV[:,:k]V[:,:k]^{T}\Lambda V% ^{T}V[:,:k]V[:,:k]^{T})- italic_V italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î› italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_V italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î› italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] italic_V [ : , : italic_k ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

Simplifying, we get:

Jğ½\displaystyle Jitalic_J =Tr(Î›âˆ’Î›[:k,:k]âˆ’Î›[:k,:k]+Î›[:k,:k])\displaystyle=\text{Tr}(\Lambda-\Lambda[:k,:k]-\Lambda[:k,:k]+\Lambda[:k,:k])= Tr ( roman_Î› - roman_Î› [ : italic_k , : italic_k ] - roman_Î› [ : italic_k , : italic_k ] + roman_Î› [ : italic_k , : italic_k ] )
=Tr(Î›)âˆ’Tr(Î›[:k,:k])\displaystyle=\text{Tr}(\Lambda)-\text{Tr}(\Lambda[:k,:k])= Tr ( roman_Î› ) - Tr ( roman_Î› [ : italic_k , : italic_k ] )
=âˆ‘i=k+1MÎ»iabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘€subscriptğœ†ğ‘–\displaystyle=\sum_{i=k+1}^{M}\lambda_{i}= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Therefore, the minimum sum of squared distances from M vectors to a k-dimensional subspace is âˆ‘i=k+1MÎ»isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘€subscriptğœ†ğ‘–\sum_{i=k+1}^{M}\lambda_{i}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th eigenvalue of XTâ¢Xsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡ğ‘‹X^{T}Xitalic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X.

Remark 7.

This result is essentially the property of dimensionality reduction of M vectors to k-dimensional.

Definition 3 (Minimum Projection Distance to Cone Surface).

Given a cone CâŠ†â„nğ¶superscriptâ„ğ‘›C\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_C âŠ† blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with surface âˆ‚Cğ¶\partial Câˆ‚ italic_C, and any vector ğ¯âˆˆCğ¯ğ¶\mathbf{v}\in Cbold_v âˆˆ italic_C, we define Lâ¢(ğ¯,âˆ‚C)ğ¿ğ¯ğ¶L(\mathbf{v},\partial C)italic_L ( bold_v , âˆ‚ italic_C ) as the minimum distance (projection distance) from ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v}bold_v to the surface of Cğ¶Citalic_C. Formally:

Lâ¢(ğ¯,âˆ‚C)=minğ±âˆˆâˆ‚Câ¡â€–ğ¯âˆ’ğ±â€–ğ¿ğ¯ğ¶subscriptğ±ğ¶normğ¯ğ±L(\mathbf{v},\partial C)=\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\partial C}\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{x}\|italic_L ( bold_v , âˆ‚ italic_C ) = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_v - bold_x âˆ¥ (81)
Definition 4 (The angle to boundary and the aperture of the cone).

For any interior point xğ‘¥xitalic_x of a convex cone Cğ¶Citalic_C, we define:

(i) The minimum distance from xğ‘¥xitalic_x to the boundary of Cğ¶Citalic_C:

dâ¢(x,âˆ‚C)=minâ¡{â€–xâˆ’yâ€–âˆ£yâˆˆâˆ‚C}=dâ¢(x,projCâ¢(x)),ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ¶conditionalnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¦ğ¶ğ‘‘ğ‘¥subscriptprojğ¶ğ‘¥d(x,\partial C)=\min\{\|x-y\|\mid y\in\partial C\}=d(x,\text{proj}_{C}(x)),italic_d ( italic_x , âˆ‚ italic_C ) = roman_min { âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_y âˆ¥ âˆ£ italic_y âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_C } = italic_d ( italic_x , proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) ,

where projCâ¢(x)subscriptprojğ¶ğ‘¥\text{proj}_{C}(x)proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is the projection of xğ‘¥xitalic_x onto Cğ¶Citalic_C.

(ii) The cosine of the angle Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ between xğ‘¥xitalic_x and the boundary of Cğ¶Citalic_C:

cosâ¡Î¸x,C=âŸ¨x,projCâ¢(x)âŸ©â€–xâ€–â¢â€–projCâ¢(x)â€–.subscriptğœƒğ‘¥ğ¶ğ‘¥subscriptprojğ¶ğ‘¥normğ‘¥normsubscriptprojğ¶ğ‘¥\cos\theta_{x,C}=\frac{\langle x,\text{proj}_{C}(x)\rangle}{\|x\|\|\text{proj}% _{C}(x)\|}.roman_cos italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x , proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ âˆ¥ proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) âˆ¥ end_ARG .

(iii) The relationship between the distance and the angle Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸:

dâ¢(x,âˆ‚C)=â€–xâ€–â¢sinâ¡Î¸x,C.ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ¶normğ‘¥subscriptğœƒğ‘¥ğ¶d(x,\partial C)=\|x\|\sin\theta_{x,C}.italic_d ( italic_x , âˆ‚ italic_C ) = âˆ¥ italic_x âˆ¥ roman_sin italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

(iv) The aperture Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦ of the cone

sinâ¡(Î¦)=maxv,uâˆˆCâ¡(|<v,u>â€–vâ€–â‹…â€–uâ€–|)\sin(\Phi)=\max_{v,u\in C}(|\frac{<v,u>}{\|v\|\cdot\|u\|}|)roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_u âˆˆ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( | divide start_ARG < italic_v , italic_u > end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_u âˆ¥ end_ARG | )

Moreover, for any interior point xğ‘¥xitalic_x, we have Î¸x,Câ‰¤Î¦/2subscriptğœƒğ‘¥ğ¶Î¦2\theta_{x,C}\leq\Phi/2italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_Î¦ / 2. This formulation is based on the Distance-Support Theorem by Rockafellar (1970).

Lemma 12 (Relationship between Range of Prompted and Embedding matrix).

As mentioned in lemma 3, VÎ±1=VÎ±={Ïƒâ¢(ğ¯)âˆ£ğ¯âˆˆRâ¢(W)}subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘‰ğ›¼conditional-setğœğ¯ğ¯ğ‘…ğ‘ŠV^{1}_{\alpha}=V_{\alpha}=\{\sigma(\mathbf{v})\mid\mathbf{v}\in R(W)\}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_Ïƒ ( bold_v ) âˆ£ bold_v âˆˆ italic_R ( italic_W ) }. In lemma 8, under the alternating action of the non-linear function Leaky-ReLU and linear transformation Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, we have VÎ±i=Ïƒâ¢(VÎ±iâˆ’1â¢W)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1ğ›¼ğ‘ŠV^{i}_{\alpha}=\sigma(V^{i-1}_{\alpha}W)italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W ).

First prove VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a cone surface. For VÎ±1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰1ğ›¼V^{1}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, given Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0 and ğ¯âˆˆRâ¢(W)ğ¯ğ‘…ğ‘Š\mathbf{v}\in R(W)bold_v âˆˆ italic_R ( italic_W ), we have Ïƒâ¢(Î»â¢ğ¯)=Î»â¢Ïƒâ¢(ğ¯)ğœğœ†ğ¯ğœ†ğœğ¯\sigma(\lambda\mathbf{v})=\lambda\sigma(\mathbf{v})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Î» bold_v ) = italic_Î» italic_Ïƒ ( bold_v ). Thus, if Ïƒâ¢(ğ¯)âˆˆVÎ±1ğœğ¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰1ğ›¼\sigma(\mathbf{v})\in V^{1}_{\alpha}italic_Ïƒ ( bold_v ) âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then âˆ€Î»>0for-allğœ†0\forall\lambda>0âˆ€ italic_Î» > 0, Î»â¢Ïƒâ¢(ğ¯)âˆˆVÎ±1ğœ†ğœğ¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰1ğ›¼\lambda\sigma(\mathbf{v})\in V^{1}_{\alpha}italic_Î» italic_Ïƒ ( bold_v ) âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, consider ğ¯âˆˆVÎ±iâˆ’1ğ¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1ğ›¼\mathbf{v}\in V^{i-1}_{\alpha}bold_v âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, âˆ€Î»>0for-allğœ†0\forall\lambda>0âˆ€ italic_Î» > 0, Ïƒâ¢((Î»â¢ğ¯)â¢W)=Î»â¢Ïƒâ¢(ğ¯â¢W)ğœğœ†ğ¯ğ‘Šğœ†ğœğ¯ğ‘Š\sigma((\lambda\mathbf{v})W)=\lambda\sigma(\mathbf{v}W)italic_Ïƒ ( ( italic_Î» bold_v ) italic_W ) = italic_Î» italic_Ïƒ ( bold_v italic_W ). It follows that, âˆ€ğ¯âˆˆVÎ±i,âˆ€Î»>0formulae-sequencefor-allğ¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼for-allğœ†0\forall\mathbf{v}\in V^{i}_{\alpha},\forall\lambda>0âˆ€ bold_v âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ italic_Î» > 0, Î»â¢ğ¯âˆˆVÎ±iğœ†ğ¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼\lambda\mathbf{v}\in V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_Î» bold_v âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, hence, VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a cone surface. Iteratively, we obtain that VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a cone surface for iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â€¦ , italic_n }.

Next, consider CÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼C^{i}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the convex hull of VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Specifically, since VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a cone surface, CÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼C^{i}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a convex cone. By linearity of multiple a matrix, CÎ±iâ¢Wsubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ‘ŠC^{i}_{\alpha}Witalic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W remains a convex cone. After applying Ïƒâ¢(â‹…)ğœâ‹…\sigma(\cdot)italic_Ïƒ ( â‹… ), this convex hull transforms into another convex cone or cone surface, namely, Ïƒâ¢(CÎ±iâ¢W)ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ‘Š\sigma(C^{i}_{\alpha}W)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W ), and the corresponding VÎ±i+1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1ğ›¼V^{i+1}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the surface of CÎ±i+1subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–1ğ›¼C^{i+1}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Ïƒâ¢(CÎ±i)ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼\sigma(C^{i}_{\alpha})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is then the convex hull of Ïƒâ¢(CÎ±iâ¢W)ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ‘Š\sigma(C^{i}_{\alpha}W)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W ).

After nğ‘›nitalic_n iterations of the aggregation, we can conclude that: VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a cone surface, CÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼C^{i}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a convex cone, and VÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ›¼V^{i}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the surface of CÎ±isubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼C^{i}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Remark 8.

Here we assume that the process of obtaining the convex hull CÎ±i+1subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–1ğ›¼C^{i+1}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Ïƒâ¢(CÎ±iâ¢W)ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ‘Š\sigma(C^{i}_{\alpha}W)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W ) keeps the VÎ±i+1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1ğ›¼V^{i+1}_{\alpha}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be the surface of CÎ±i+1subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘–1ğ›¼C^{i+1}_{\alpha}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This always holds true unless the nonlinear transformation Ïƒâ¢(â‹…)ğœâ‹…\sigma(\cdot)italic_Ïƒ ( â‹… ) turns the convex cone VÎ±iâ¢Wsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‰ğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘ŠV_{\alpha}^{i}Witalic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W non-convex, which is unlikely when piece-wise linear function Leaky-ReLU is used as the nonlinear function as discussed in Ben-Tal & Nemirovski (2001).

Lemma 13 (Distribution of the Norm of an n-Dimensional i.i.d. Normal Vector After Multiplying Projection Matrix).

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a projection matrix onto a linear subspace Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. Then Iâˆ’Pğ¼ğ‘ƒI-Pitalic_I - italic_P is a projection matrix onto the orthogonal complement of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. Assume Ï‚ğœ\varsigmaitalic_Ï‚ is an nğ‘›nitalic_n-dimensional random vector following a normal distribution with mean ğŸ0\mathbf{0}bold_0 and covariance matrix câ¢IFğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ¹cI_{F}italic_c italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where cğ‘citalic_c is a positive constant. i.e., Ï‚âˆ¼ğ’©(ğŸ,cIF\varsigma\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0},cI_{F}italic_Ï‚ âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , italic_c italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Let Î¶=(Iâˆ’P)â‹…Ï‚ğœâ‹…ğ¼ğ‘ƒğœ\zeta=(I-P)\cdot\varsigmaitalic_Î¶ = ( italic_I - italic_P ) â‹… italic_Ï‚, according to the linear property of Gaussian Random vector, we have Î¶âˆ¼Nâ¢(Î¼â€²,Î£â€²)similar-toğœğ‘superscriptğœ‡â€²superscriptÎ£â€²\zeta\sim N(\mu^{\prime},\Sigma^{\prime})italic_Î¶ âˆ¼ italic_N ( italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where:

Î¼â€²superscriptğœ‡â€²\displaystyle\mu^{\prime}italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =(Iâˆ’P)â‹…Î¼absentâ‹…ğ¼ğ‘ƒğœ‡\displaystyle=(I-P)\cdot\mu= ( italic_I - italic_P ) â‹… italic_Î¼
=ğŸabsent0\displaystyle=\mathbf{0}= bold_0
Î£â€²superscriptÎ£â€²\displaystyle\Sigma^{\prime}roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =(Iâˆ’P)Tâ‹…Î£â‹…(Iâˆ’P)absentâ‹…superscriptğ¼ğ‘ƒğ‘‡Î£ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle=(I-P)^{T}\cdot\Sigma\cdot(I-P)= ( italic_I - italic_P ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_Î£ â‹… ( italic_I - italic_P )

Denote by rğ‘Ÿritalic_r the rank of matrix Iâˆ’Pğ¼ğ‘ƒI-Pitalic_I - italic_P.
Apply decorrelation to Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶, we have Î¹=UTâ‹…Î¶ğœ„â‹…superscriptğ‘ˆğ‘‡ğœ\iota=U^{T}\cdot\zetaitalic_Î¹ = italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_Î¶, Î¹âˆ¼Nâ¢(0â†’,Î£â€²â€²)similar-toğœ„ğ‘â†’0superscriptÎ£â€²â€²\iota\sim N(\vec{0},\Sigma^{\prime\prime})italic_Î¹ âˆ¼ italic_N ( overâ†’ start_ARG 0 end_ARG , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where Î£â€²â€²=superscriptÎ£â€²â€²absent\Sigma^{\prime\prime}=roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = (c2â‹…IrOOOFâˆ’rÃ—Fâˆ’r)matrixâ‹…superscriptğ‘2subscriptğ¼ğ‘Ÿğ‘‚ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘‚ğ¹ğ‘Ÿğ¹ğ‘Ÿ\begin{pmatrix}c^{2}\cdot I_{r}&O\\ O&O_{F-r\times F-r}\end{pmatrix}( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_O end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_O end_CELL start_CELL italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F - italic_r Ã— italic_F - italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ), Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U is a orthogonal matrix. Hence,

â€–(Iâˆ’P)â¢Ï‚â€–=â€–Î¹â€–=âˆ‘i=1rÎ¹i2normğ¼ğ‘ƒğœnormğœ„subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1subscriptsuperscriptğœ„2ğ‘–\|(I-P)\varsigma\|=\|\iota\|=\sqrt{\sum^{r}_{i=1}\iota^{2}_{i}}âˆ¥ ( italic_I - italic_P ) italic_Ï‚ âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ italic_Î¹ âˆ¥ = square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG

Since âˆ‘i=1rÎ¹i2âˆ¼Ï‡2â¢(r)similar-tosubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1subscriptsuperscriptğœ„2ğ‘–superscriptğœ’2ğ‘Ÿ\sum^{r}_{i=1}\iota^{2}_{i}\sim\chi^{2}(r)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ), we have: â€–Î¶â€–=âˆ‘i=1rÎ¹i2âˆ¼Ï‡â¢(r)normğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1subscriptsuperscriptğœ„2ğ‘–similar-toğœ’ğ‘Ÿ\|\zeta\|=\sqrt{\sum^{r}_{i=1}\iota^{2}_{i}}\sim\chi(r)âˆ¥ italic_Î¶ âˆ¥ = square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¼ italic_Ï‡ ( italic_r )

It follows that the norm of an n-dimensional i.i.d. normal vector after multiplying projection matrix: â€–(Iâˆ’P)â¢Ï‚â€–normğ¼ğ‘ƒğœ\|(I-P)\varsigma\|âˆ¥ ( italic_I - italic_P ) italic_Ï‚ âˆ¥ obey Chi-Distribution with r degrees of freedom.

Appendix B Supplementary Experiments

We conducted supplementary experiments on real-world datasets to validate our results. We performed similar experiments as in the main text using entirely different datasets, namely NCI1 and DD Morris etÂ al. (2020). The NCI1 dataset has 37-dimensional node features, 4,110 subgraphs, an average of 29.87 nodes per subgraph, and an average of 64.60 edges per subgraph. The DD dataset has 89-dimensional node features, 1,178 subgraphs, an average of 284.32 nodes per subgraph, and an average of 1,431.32 edges per subgraph. Our results are shown in the following figures.

Exp1 we examined the loss curves during training for GPF and All-in-one prompting methods with full-rank matrices. Similar to observations from synthetic datasets, the prompt method shows a period of steady decline followed by a rapid decrease to a small magnitude, then slowly converging to zero. This aligns with our theoretical results.

Exp 2 we investigated the relationship between empirical maximum error and rank loss for non-full-rank matrices. The results here are similar to those in the main text, with loss (empirical maximum error) increasing as rank loss increases. Where rank loss is rğ‘Ÿritalic_r means the rank of weight matrix Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W in GNN is nâˆ’rğ‘›ğ‘Ÿn-ritalic_n - italic_r.

Exp 3 We examined how the RMSE of GPF or single-node All-in-one Prompt methods change as the number of graphs increases in multiple graph mapping scenarios. We observed that in real-world datasets, RMSE also increases rapidly as the number of graphs increases, which aligns with our observation in the main experiment.

Appendix C EXPERIMENT DETAILS

Data Preparation: We first confirm our theoretical findings on synthetic datasets because these datasets offer controlled environments, allowing us to isolate specific variables and study their impacts. We generate these datasets by defining the dimension of graph feature vector(Fğ¹Fitalic_F), average of graph node numbers (Naâ¢vâ¢gsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”N_{avg}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_v italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), average of graph edge numbers (Eaâ¢vâ¢gsubscriptğ¸ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”E_{avg}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_v italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and number of graphs in the dataset (Mğ‘€Mitalic_M). These parameters characterize both individual graphs and the entire dataset, facilitating our study of the relationship between these features and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ. In detail, the distribution of graph node feature vectors is set to a normal distribution ğ’©â¢(0,1)ğ’©01\mathcal{N}(0,1)caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ); the graph edge density ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is set to 0.150.150.150.15, where ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï represents the probability of an edge existing between any two nodes.

Model Settings: We utilize two GNN frameworks: GCN (representing linear models) and GAT (representing non-linear models). We limit our experiments to these two models as other models follow similar patterns. Unless otherwise specified, we use a 3-layer GNN with Leaky-ReLU activation function and feature dimension F=25ğ¹25F=25italic_F = 25. For full-rank matrix studies, we ensure each layerâ€™s matrix is full-rank (selected after pre-training). For non-full-rank matrix studies, we set the rank loss to 5555 by default. The default ReadOut method is mean pooling.

Task Settings: Our loss function is defined as â€–FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gp)âˆ’Câ¢(G)â€–normsubscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ¶ğº\|F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{p})-C(G)\|âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ for single-graph tasks, and âˆ‘Gâˆˆğ’¢â€–FÎ¸âˆ—â¢(Gp)âˆ’Câ¢(G)â€–2/Msubscriptğºğ’¢superscriptnormsubscriptğ¹superscriptğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘ğ¶ğº2ğ‘€\sqrt{\sum_{G\in\mathcal{G}}\|F_{\theta^{*}}(G_{p})-C(G)\|^{2}/M}square-root start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G âˆˆ caligraphic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_M end_ARG for multi-graph tasks. Here Gpsubscriptğºğ‘G_{p}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the combined graph with GğºGitalic_G and graph prompt. Kindly note that Câ¢(G)ğ¶ğºC(G)italic_C ( italic_G ) means an optimal function to the downstream task, which is not accessible without a specific task. Since the ultimate purpose of graph prompting is to approximate graph operation, we here treat Câ¢(â‹…)ğ¶â‹…C(\cdot)italic_C ( â‹… ) as various graph data operations such as adding/deleting nodes, adding/deleting/changing edges, and transforming features of a given graph GğºGitalic_G. The intensity of these graph operations is controlled by a parameter Î²âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›½01\beta\in[0,1]italic_Î² âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], where 0 indicates no change and 1 indicates generating a completely random new graph. In our experiments, we fix Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² at 0.70.70.70.7, which means we have a 0.70.70.70.7 probability of removing a node/edge or masking some features.

Training: In the graph prompting training process, we perform gradient descent on the parameters Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ of the graph prompt PÏ‰subscriptğ‘ƒğœ”P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï‰ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the Adam optimizer. We use a learning rate of 1Ã—10âˆ’41superscript1041\times 10^{-4}1 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and weight decay of 5Ã—10âˆ’55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}5 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We implement an early stopping mechanism with a maximum of 2000 epochs by default. When analyzing the upper bound of the error of the prompt method, it is crucial to ensure that the convergence value of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is indeed the global minimum. To prevent the training of prompt parameters from falling into local minima, we approximate the global minimum by independently training kğ‘˜kitalic_k times with random initialization for each prompt, and selecting the minimum loss. Typically, kğ‘˜kitalic_k is set to 3.

Testing: Note that the error bound in Theorem 5 is the product of two terms: sinâ¡(Î¦/2)Î¦2\sin(\Phi/2)roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ) and â€–Câ¢(G)â€–normğ¶ğº\|C(G)\|âˆ¥ italic_C ( italic_G ) âˆ¥. For a fixed pre-trained model, sinâ¡(Î¦/2)Î¦2\sin(\Phi/2)roman_sin ( roman_Î¦ / 2 ) is consistent, but Câ¢(G)ğ¶ğºC(G)italic_C ( italic_G ) varies with different generated datasets. In our experiments, the 30 graphs used to find the empirical maximum value are from the same dataset, while the different empirical maximum values are obtained from different datasets. Considering the average value better represents the change in the Error Bound relative to the independent variables like â€œRank Lostâ€.
